page.title: List of English inventions and discoveries

revision.text:
{{Culture of England}} '''English inventions and discoveries''' are objects, processes or techniques invented, innovated or discovered, partially or entirely, in [[England]] by a person from England (that is, someone born in England – including to non-English parents – or born abroad with at least one English parent and who had the majority of their education or career in England). Often, things [[Discovery (observation)|discovered]] for the first time are also called inventions and in many cases, there is no clear line between the two.
The following is a list of inventions, innovations or discoveries known or generally recognised to be English.
{{Dynamic list}}
==Agriculture== [[File:Jethro Tull (agriculturist).jpg|thumb|150px|[[Jethro Tull (agriculturist)|Jethro Tull]], improved the [[seed drill]] in 1701]] * 1627: Publication of first experiments in [[Water desalination]] and [[Water purification|filtration]] by Sir [[Francis Bacon]] (1561–1626).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lenntech.com/history-water-treatment.htm |title=History of water treatment |publisher=lenntech.com |accessdate=22 January 2011 }}</ref> * 1701: [[Seed drill]] improved by [[Jethro Tull (agriculturist)|Jethro Tull]] (1674–1741). *18th century: of the horse-drawn [[hoe (tool)|hoe]] and scarifier by [[Jethro Tull (agriculturist)|Jethro Tull]]<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.tiscali.co.uk/reference/encyclopaedia/hutchinson/m0006239.html |title = Tiscali encyclopaedia: Seed drill |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060709145302/http://www.tiscali.co.uk/reference/encyclopaedia/hutchinson/m0006239.html |archivedate = 2006-07-09 |df = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/tull_jethro.shtml|title=Jethro Tull (1674 – 1741)|publisher=BBC|accessdate=2011-11-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=The Cambridge economic history of modern Britain|first=Roderick|last=Floud|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2004|isbn=978-0-521-52736-1|page=128}}</ref> * 1780s: [[Selective breeding]] and [[artificial selection]] pioneered by [[Robert Bakewell (agriculturalist)|Robert Bakewell]] (1725–1795).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/bakewell_robert.shtml|title=Robert Bakewell (1725 – 1795). |work=bbc.co.uk/history. |publisher=[[BBC]] }}</ref> * 1842: [[Superphosphate]] or [[chemical fertilizer]] developed by [[John Bennet Lawes]] (1814–1900).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://education.yahoo.com/reference/encyclopedia/entry/Lawes-Si |title=superphosphate-John Bennet Lawes |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121002122816/http://education.yahoo.com/reference/encyclopedia/entry/Lawes-Si |archivedate=2012-10-02 |df= }}</ref> * 1850s: [[Steam engine|Steam]]-driven [[plough]]ing engine invented by [[John Fowler (agricultural engineer)|John Fowler]] (1826–1864).<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.steamploughclub.org.uk/history.htm |title = steamploughclub:Steam-driven ploughing engine-John Fowler |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100612025329/http://www.steamploughclub.org.uk/history.htm |archivedate = 2010-06-12 |df = }}</ref> * 1901: First commercially successful light farm-[[tractor]] invented by [[Dan Albone]] (1860–1906).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scienceandsociety.co.uk/results.asp?image=10307483&wwwflag=2&imagepos=1|title=Science Museum London}}</ref> * 1930s onwards: Developments in [[dairy farming]] systems pioneered by [[Rex Paterson]] (1902–1978).<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Paterson, Rex (1955). Fertilizer Distribution – Problems of Corrosion Prevention on the Farm. The International Fertilizer Society (Proceeding 32).|postscript=<!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref>
==Ceramics== * 1748: Fine [[Soft-paste porcelain|porcelain]] developed by [[Thomas Frye]] (c. 1710–1762), of [[Bow porcelain factory]], London.<ref>Frye's epitaph, describing him as "the inventor and first manufacturer of porcelain in England" published in ''Supplement to [[The Gentleman's Magazine]] for the Year 1764'', p. 638.</ref> Cf. Frye's rivals at [[Chelsea porcelain factory]]. * 1770s: [[Jasperware]] developed by [[Josiah Wedgwood]] (1730–1795).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/wedgwood_josiah.shtml |title=Josiah Wedgwood (1730–1795) |publisher=[[BBC History]] |accessdate=28 June 2016 }}</ref> * 1789–1793: [[Bone china]] created by [[Josiah Spode]] (1733–1797).<ref>{{cite journal |last=Ozgundogdu |first=Feyza Cakir |date=May 2005 |title=Bone China from Turkey |journal=Ceramics Technical |volume=20 |pages=29–32 }}</ref> * 1813: [[Ironstone china]] invented by Charles James Mason (1791–1856).<ref>{{cite journal|title=Mason's Ironstone Retains Its Decorative Tradition|journal=International Tableware|year=1991|volume=21|issue=3}}</ref>
==Clock making== [[File:Anchor Escapement.png|thumb|120px|[[Anchor escapement]], c. 1657]] * [[Anglo-Saxons|Anglo-Saxon]] times: type of [[candle clock]] invented by [[Alfred the Great]] (849-899).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://kids.britannica.com/clockworks/t_candle.html |title=Candle clock |publisher=Britannica.com |accessdate=6 January 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151126001057/http://kids.britannica.com/clockworks/t_candle.html |archivedate=26 November 2015 |df= }}</ref> * c. 1657: [[Anchor escapement]] probably invented by [[Robert Hooke]] (1635–1703).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abbeyclock.com/anchor.html |title=The Origin and Evolution of the Anchor Clock Escapement |publisher=Abbey Clock |accessdate=14 January 2016 }}</ref> * c. 1657: [[Balance spring]] added to [[balance wheel]] by [[Robert Hooke]] (1635–1703).<ref>A. R. Hall, "Horology and criticism: Robert Hooke", Studia Copernicana, XVI, Ossolineum, 1978, 261-81</ref><ref name="dicteng">{{cite book|title=A Biographical Dictionary of People in Engineering: From the Earliest Records to 2000|first=Carl|last=Hall|year=2008|publisher=Purdue University Press|isbn=978-1-55753-459-0}}</ref> * c. 1722: [[Grasshopper escapement]] invented by [[John Harrison]] (1693–1776); Harrison created the H1, H2, H3 & H4 watches (to solve the [[longitude]] measurement problem).<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/1864737.stm |title=Longitude clock comes alive |date=2002-03-11 | work=BBC News | accessdate=2010-01-03}}</ref> * c. 1726: [[Gridiron pendulum]] invented by [[John Harrison]] (1693–1776).<ref name="dicteng"/> * c. 1755: [[Lever escapement]], the greatest single improvement ever applied to [[pocket watch]]es, invented by [[Thomas Mudge (horologist)|Thomas Mudge]] (1715–1794).<ref name="dicteng"/> * 1761: First true [[Marine chronometer]] perfected by [[John Harrison]] (1693–1776).<ref name="dicteng"/> * 1923: [[Self-winding watch]] invented by [[John Harwood (watchmaker)|John Harwood]] (1893–1964).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atquid.com/viewArticle.php?article_id=59&title=The_Harwood_Automatic_Wristwatch |title=The Harwood Pioneer Automatic Wristwatch |accessdate=2012-05-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150622180532/http://www.atquid.com/viewArticle.php?article_id=59&title=The_Harwood_Automatic_Wristwatch |archivedate=June 22, 2015 }}</ref> * 1955: First accurate [[atomic clock]] invented by [[Louis Essen]] (1908–1997).<ref> {{Cite journal |author1=L. Essen |author2=J.V.L. Parry |year=1955 |title=An Atomic Standard of Frequency and Time Interval: A Caesium Resonator |journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]] |volume=176 |issue=4476 |pages=280–282 |doi=10.1038/176280a0 |bibcode=1955Natur.176..280E }}</ref> * 1976: [[Coaxial escapement]] mechanism invented by [[George Daniels (watchmaker)|George Daniels]] (1926–2011).
==Clothing manufacturing== * 1589: The [[stocking frame]], a mechanical [[knitting machine]] used in the [[textiles]] industry, invented by [[William Lee (inventor)|William Lee]] (1563–1614). * 1733: The [[flying shuttle]], a key development in the [[Textile manufacture during the Industrial Revolution|industrialization]] of [[weaving]] during the early [[Industrial Revolution]], invented by [[John Kay (flying shuttle)|John Kay]] of [[Walmersley]] (1704-c. 1779). [[File:La revolucion industrial.jpg|thumb|The [[spinning jenny]], invented in 1764 by [[James Hargreaves]]]] * 1759: The ''Derby Rib'' machine (for [[stocking]] manufacture) invented by [[Jedediah Strutt]] (1726–1797).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.knittingtogether.org.uk/doc.asp?doc=14056&cat=665 |title=Jedediah Strutt (1726–1797) – Inventor of the Derby Rib Machine |publisher=Knitting Together |accessdate=10 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060923121040/http://www.knittingtogether.org.uk/doc.asp?doc=14056&cat=665 |archivedate=23 September 2006 |df= }}</ref> * 1764: The [[spinning jenny]] invented by [[James Hargreaves]] (c. 1720–1778). * 1767: [[Spinning frame]] invented by [[John Kay (spinning frame)|John Kay]] of [[Warrington]]. * 1769: The [[water frame]], a water-powered [[spinning frame]], developed by [[Richard Arkwright]] (1732–1792). * 1775–1779: [[Spinning mule]] invented by [[Samuel Crompton]] (1753–1827). * 1784: [[Power loom]] invented by [[Edmund Cartwright]] (1743–1823). * 1790: [[Sewing machine]] invented by Thomas Saint.<ref name="oreilly">{{cite book|title=Did Thomas Crapper Really Invent the Toilet?: The Inventions That Changed Our Homes and Our Lives|author=Catherine O'Reilly|year=2008|publisher=Skyhorse Publishing|isbn=978-1-60239-347-9}}</ref> * 1808: The [[bobbinet]], a development on the warp-[[loom]], invented by [[John Heathcoat]] (1783–1861). * 1856: [[Mauveine]], the first synthetic organic dye, discovered by [[Sir William Henry Perkin|William Henry Perkin]] (1838–1907). * 1941: [[Polyester]] invented by [[John Rex Whinfield]] (1901–1966).
==Communications== * Pre-1565: The [[pencil]] invented in [[Seathwaite, Allerdale|Seathwaite]], [[Borrowdale]], [[Cumbria]], using [[Grey Knotts]] [[graphite]]. * 1588: Modern [[shorthand]] invented by [[Timothy Bright]] (1551?–1615). * 1661: The [[postmark]] (called the "Bishop Mark") introduced by English [[United Kingdom Postmaster General|Postmaster General]] [[Henry Bishop (postmaster general)|Henry Bishop]] (1611–1691/2).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/h2g2/alabaster/A1082558 |title=History of the Postal Service |publisher=BBC |date=2003-07-24 |accessdate=2009-02-22}}</ref> * 1667: [[Tin can telephone]], a device that conveyed sounds over an extended wire by mechanical vibrations, invented by [[Robert Hooke]] (1635–1703).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.roberthooke.org.uk/micro2.htm|title=Micrographia – Extracts From The Preface}}</ref> * 1714: Patent for an apparatus regarded as the first [[typewriter]] granted to [[Henry Mill]] (c. 1683–1771).<ref>{{cite book|title=Type and typography|author1=Phil Baines|author2=Andrew Haslam|year=2005|publisher=Laurence King|isbn=978-1-85669-437-7}}</ref> * 18th century: The [[Valentine's Day|Valentine's card]] first popularised.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emotionscards.com/museum/vals.html|title=The History of Valentine's Day Cards ~ Valentine History ~ The Valentine Gallery Page One – Emotions Greeting Cards Museum|website=Emotionscards.com|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref> * 1822: The [[mechanical pencil]] patented by [[Sampson Mordan]] (1790–1843) and [[John Isaac Hawkins]] (1772–1855).<ref>{{cite book|title=Pen, ink, & evidence: a study of writing and writing materials for the penman, collector, and document detective|author=Joe Nickell|authorlink=Joe Nickell|year=2000|publisher=Oak Knoll Press|isbn=978-1-58456-017-3}}</ref> * 1831: [[Electromagnetic induction]] & [[Faraday's law of induction]]. Began as a series of experiments by [[Michael Faraday]] (1791–1867); later became some of the first experiments in the discovery of [[radio waves]] and the development of [[radio]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theiet.org/about/libarc/archives/biographies/faraday.cfm |title=Archives Biographies: Michael Faraday", The Institution of Engineering and Technology |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929004417/http://www.theiet.org/about/libarc/archives/biographies/faraday.cfm |archivedate=2011-09-29 |df= }}</ref> * 1837: The first ''commercially'' successful [[electric telegraph]] developed by Sir [[Charles Wheatstone]] (1802–1875) and Sir [[William Fothergill Cooke]] (1806–1879).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cntr.salford.ac.uk/comms/johntawell.php|title=The development of the electric telegraph}}</ref><ref name="kcl_wheatstone"/><ref name="bowers_wheatstone"/> * 1837: [[Pitman Shorthand]] invented by [[Isaac Pitman]] (1813–1897). [[File:Penny Black VR.jpg|thumb|160px|[[Postage stamp]], invented by [[Rowland Hill (postal reformer)|Sir Rowland Hill]], 1840]] * 1840: [[Uniform Penny Post]] and [[postage stamp]] invented by [[Rowland Hill (postal reformer)|Sir Rowland Hill]] (1795–1879).<ref name="postalheritage.wordpress.com">{{cite web|url=http://postalheritage.wordpress.com/2009/08/21/rowland-hill%E2%80%99s-postal-reforms/|title=Rowland Hill’s Postal Reforms|date=21 August 2009|website=Postalheritage.wordpress.com|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref> * 1843: The [[Christmas card]] introduced commercially by [[Henry Cole|Sir Henry Cole]] (1808–1882).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/devon/news_features/2004/christmas_cards.shtml |title=Christmas greetings...from Torquay |publisher=BBC |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref> * 1873: Discovery of the [[photoconductivity]] of the element [[selenium]] by [[Willoughby Smith]] (1828–1891). Smith's work led to the invention of [[photoelectric cell]]s ([[solar panels]]), including those used in the earliest [[television]] systems. * 1879: The first [[radio]] transmission, using a [[spark-gap transmitter]] (achieving a range of approximately 500 metres), made by [[David E. Hughes]] (1831–1900). * 1897: The world's first [[radio station]] was located at [[The Needles Batteries]] on the western tip of the [[Isle of Wight]]; it was set up by [[Guglielmo Marconi|Marconi]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Lee|first1=Eric|title=How internet radio can change the world : an activist's handbook|date=2005|publisher=iUniversr, Inc.|location=New York|isbn=9780595349654|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Md0aYx9jql8C&pg=PA7&lpg=PA7&dq=The+world%27s+first+radio+station+on+the+Isle+of+Wight&source=bl&ots=XCRWbedOOv&sig=1v4FClecm_J_p63C6oxOd8UNZFo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=H4QOVc3hL4frUsmBgYgC&ved=0CFAQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=The%20world's%20first%20radio%20station%20on%20the%20Isle%20of%20Wight&f=false|accessdate=22 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Connected Earth |url=http://www.connected-earth.com/Journeys/Firstgenerationtechnologies/Awirelessworld/Theoriginsofradio/index.htm |accessdate=22 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402110146/http://www.connected-earth.com/Journeys/Firstgenerationtechnologies/Awirelessworld/Theoriginsofradio/index.htm |archivedate= 2 April 2015 |df= }}</ref> * 1899: The world's first [[Color motion picture film|colour motion picture film]] produced by [[Edward Raymond Turner]] (1873–1903). * 1902: Proposition by [[Oliver Heaviside]] (1850–1925) of the existence of the [[Kennelly–Heaviside layer]], a layer of [[ionised gas]] that reflects [[radio waves]] around the Earth's curvature. * 1912: Development of [[radio communication]] pioneered by [[William Eccles]] (1875–1966). * 1914: The world's first automatic [[totalisator]] invented by English-born [[George Julius]] (1873–1946). * 2 December 1922: Mechanical scanning device (a precursor to modern [[television]]) demonstrated in [[Sorbonne]], France by Englishman Edwin Belin. * 1930: The [[Plessey]] company in England began manufacturing the [[Baird Televisor]] receiver: the first television receiver sold to the public. * 1931: [[Stereophonic sound]] or, more commonly, stereo invented at [[EMI]] in [[Hayes, Hillingdon|Hayes, Middlesex]] by [[Alan Blumlein]] (1903–1942).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abbeyroad.com/news/story/?newsid=22|title=Alan Blumlein – the man who invented stereo|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100917063444/http://abbeyroad.com/news/story/?newsid=22|archivedate=2010-09-17|df=}}</ref> * 1933: The [[405-line television system]] (the first fully electronic television system used in regular [[broadcasting]]) developed at [[EMI]] in [[Hayes, Hillingdon|Hayes, Middlesex]] by [[Alan Blumlein]] (1903–1942), under the supervision of Sir [[Isaac Shoenberg]]. * 1936: The world's first regular public broadcasts of high-definition [[television]] began from [[Alexandra Palace]], [[North London]] by the [[BBC Television Service]]. * 1930s: [[Radar]] pioneered at [[Bawdsey Manor]] by Scotsman [[Robert Watson-Watt]] (1892–1973) and Englishman [[Henry Tizard]] (1885–1939). * 1945: The concept of [[geostationary satellites]] for the use of [[telecommunications]] relays popularised by [[Arthur C. Clarke]] (1917–2008). * 1964 onwards: Use of [[fibre optics]] in [[telecommunications]] pioneered by Englishman [[George Hockham]] (1938–2013) and Chinese-born [[Charles K. Kao]]. * Late 1960s: Development of the long-lasting materials that made [[liquid crystal displays]] possible. Team headed by [[Brynmor Jones Library|Sir Brynmor Jones]]; developed by Scotsman [[George William Gray|George Gray]] and Englishman Ken Harrison in conjunction with the [[Royal Radar Establishment]] and the [[University of Hull]], who ultimately discovered the crystals used in LCDs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hull.ac.uk/chemistry/landmark.php|title=RSC Historic Chemical Landmark Award – Liquid Crystals}}</ref> * 1970: The [[MTV-1]], the first near pocket-sized [[handheld television]], developed by Sir [[Clive Sinclair]] (born 1940). * 1973: First transmissions of the [[Teletext]] information service made by the [[BBC|British Broadcasting Corporation]]. * 1992: [[Clockwork radio]] invented by [[Trevor Baylis]] (1937–2018).<ref>{{cite web |url = http://windupradio.com/trevor.htm |title = About TREVOR BAYLIS the inventor of the windup technology |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110924092817/http://windupradio.com/trevor.htm |archivedate = 2011-09-24 |df = }}</ref> * 3 December 1992: The world's first [[Text messaging|text]]/[[SMS]] message ("Merry Christmas") sent over the [[Vodafone]] GSM network by [[Neil Papworth]] (born 1969). * 2016: [[Holography|Holographic]] [[Television|TV]] device created by the [[BBC]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/internet/entries/408fb9a1-0891-463e-93f2-0310718d60b6 |title=BBC experiments with 'Holographic' TV |publisher=Britannica.com |accessdate=6 January 2017}}</ref>
==Computing== [[File:Tim Berners-Lee-Knight-crop.jpg|thumb|160px|Sir [[Tim Berners-Lee]], invented the [[World Wide Web]] in 1989]] [[File:CharlesBabbage.jpg|thumb|140px|"[[Computer pioneer|Father of the computer]]", [[Charles Babbage]] (1791–1871)]] * 1822: The [[Difference Engine]], an automatic [[mechanical calculator]] designed to tabulate [[polynomial]] functions, proposed by [[Charles Babbage]] (1791–1871).<ref name="Babbage">{{cite web |url=http://www.fourmilab.ch/babbage/hpb1910.html |title=From the Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society 70, 517-526, 645 (Errata) (1910) By Major-General H. P. Babbage}}</ref> * 1837: The [[Analytical Engine]], a proposed mechanical [[general-purpose computer]], designed by [[Charles Babbage]] (1791–1871).<ref name="Babbage" /> * 1842: The person regarded as the first computer [[programmer]] was [[Ada Lovelace]] (1815–1852), only legitimate child of the poet [[Lord Byron|Byron]] and his wife [[Anne Isabella Byron, Baroness Byron|Anne Isabella Milbanke]], Baroness Wentworth.<ref>[http://www.biography.com/people/ada-lovelace-20825323 Ada Lovelace Biography], biography.com</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Fuegi|Francis|2003|pp=16–26}}.</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Phillips|first=Ana Lena|title=Crowdsourcing gender equity: Ada Lovelace Day, and its companion website, aims to raise the profile of women in science and technology|journal=American Scientist|date=November–December 2011|volume=99|issue=6|page=463}}</ref><ref name="Lovelace Google">{{Cite news|date=10 December 2012|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2012/dec/10/ada-lovelace-honoured-google-doodle|title=Ada Lovelace honoured by Google doodle|newspaper=The Guardian|accessdate=10 December 2012}}</ref> * 1842: First programming language, the [[Analytical Engine]] order code, produced by [[Charles Babbage]] (1791–1871) and [[Ada Lovelace]] (1815–1852). * 1854: [[Boolean algebra (logic)|Boolean algebra]], the basis for [[Digital electronics|digital logic]], conceived by [[George Boole]] (1815–1864). * 1912: [[Argo system]], the world's first electrically powered mechanical [[analogue computer]], invented by [[Arthur Pollen]] (1866–1937). * 1918: The [[Flip-flop (electronics)|flip-flop]] circuit, which became the basis of electronic memory ([[Random-access memory]]) in computers, invented by [[William Eccles]] (1875–1966) and [[F. W. Jordan]] (1882-?). * 1936–1937: The [[Universal Turing machine]] invented by [[Alan Turing]] (1912–1954).<ref name="Turing" /> The UTM is considered to be the origin of the [[Stored program computer|stored programme computer]] used in 1946 for the "Electronic Computing Instrument" that now bears [[John von Neumann]]'s name: the [[Von Neumann architecture]]. * 1939: The [[Bombe]], a device used by the British to decipher [[Germany|German]] secret messages during [[World War II]], invented by [[Alan Turing]] (1912–1954).<ref name="Turing">{{cite web |url=http://www-history.mcs.st-andrews.ac.uk/Biographies/Turing.html |title=Turing biography}}</ref> * 1943–1944: The [[Colossus computer]] – the world's first [[Computer programming|programmable]], [[electronics|electronic]], [[Digital electronics|digital]] computer – invented by [[Tommy Flowers]] (1905–1988).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ivorcatt.com/47c.htm |title=Annals of the History of Computing, Volume 5, Number 3, July 1983 . p239, ''The Design of Colossus'', THOMAS H. FLOWERS}}</ref> * 1946–1950: [[Automatic Computing Engine|ACE]] and [[Pilot ACE]] invented by [[Alan Turing]] (1912–1954).<ref name="Turing" /> * 1946–1947: The [[Williams tube]], a [[cathode ray tube]] used to store electronically (500 to 1,000 bits of) [[binary data]], developed by [[Frederic Calland Williams]] (1911–1977) and [[Tom Kilburn]] (1921–2001). * 1948: The [[Manchester Baby]] – the world's first electronic [[Stored-program computer|stored-programme computer]] – built by [[Frederic Calland Williams]] (1911–1977) and [[Tom Kilburn]] (1921–2001) at the [[Victoria University of Manchester]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/7465115.stm|title=One tonne 'Baby' marks its birth|author=Jonathan Fildes|date=20 June 2008|accessdate=2010-12-07|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> * 1949: The [[Manchester Mark 1]] computer developed by [[Frederic Calland Williams]] (1911–1977) and [[Tom Kilburn]] (1921–2001); historically significant because of its pioneering inclusion of [[index register]]s. * 1949: [[EDSAC]] – the first complete, fully functional computer inspired by the [[von Neumann architecture]], the basis of every modern computer – constructed by [[Maurice Wilkes]] (1913–2010). * Late 1940s/early 1950s: The [[integrated circuit]], commonly called the ''microchip'', conceptualised and built by [[Geoffrey Dummer]] (1909–2002). * February 1951: The [[Ferranti Mark 1]] (a.k.a. the ''Manchester Electronic Computer''), the world's first successful commercially available general-purpose [[Electronics|electronic]] computer, invented by [[Frederic Calland Williams]] (1911–1977) and [[Tom Kilburn]] (1921–2001). * 1951: The first known recordings of [[computer generated music]] played on the [[Ferranti Mark 1]] computer using a programme designed by [[Christopher Strachey]] (1916–1975). * 1951: [[LEO (computer)|LEO]] made history by running the first business application (payroll system) on an electronic computer for [[J. Lyons and Co.]] Under the advice of [[Maurice Wilkes]] (1913–2010), LEO was designed by [[John Pinkerton (computer designer)|John Pinkerton]] (1919–1997) and [[David Caminer]] (1915–2008). * 1951: Concept of [[microprogramming]] developed by [[Maurice Wilkes]] (1913–2010) from the realisation that the [[Central Processing Unit]] (CPU) of a computer could be controlled by a miniature, highly specialised computer programme in high-speed [[Read-only memory|ROM]]. * 1952: [[Autocode]] developed by [[Alick Glennie]] (1925–2003) for the [[Manchester Mark 1]] computer; Autocode is regarded as the first computer [[compiler]]. * 1952: The first graphical computer game, ''OXO'' or ''Noughts and Crosses'', programmed on the [[EDSAC]] at [[Cambridge University]] as part of a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] thesis by [[A.S. Douglas]] (1921–2010). * 1952: First [[trackball]] built by Tom Cranston, Fred Longstaff and [[Kenyon Taylor]] (1908–1996); invented 1947 by [[Ralph Benjamin]]. * 1956 onwards: [[Metrovick 950]], the first commercial [[transistor computer]], built by the [[Metropolitan-Vickers]] Company of [[Manchester]]. * 1958: [[EDSAC 2]], the first computer to have a microprogrammed ([[Microcode]]) [[control unit]] and a [[bit slice]] hardware architecture, developed by a team headed by [[Maurice Wilkes]] (1913–2010). * 1961: The [[Sumlock ANITA calculator]], the world's first all-electronic desktop [[calculator]], designed and built by the [[Bell Punch]] Company of [[Uxbridge]]. * 1962: The [[Atlas Computer]] – arguably the world's first [[supercomputer]], and fastest computer in the world until the American [[CDC 6600]] – developed by a team headed by [[Tom Kilburn]] (1921–2001). Introduced modern architectural concepts: [[spooling]], [[interrupts]], [[pipelining]], [[interleaved memory]], [[virtual memory]], and [[paging]]. * Late 1960s: [[Denotational semantics]] originated in the work of [[Christopher Strachey]] (1916–1975), a pioneer in programming language design. * 1970: [[Packet switching]] co-invented by Welsh engineer [[Donald Davies]] (1924–2000) and Polish-born [[Paul Baran]]; it was Davies who coined the term ''packet switching'' at the [[National Physical Laboratory (United Kingdom)|National Physical Laboratory]] in London. * 1972: The [[Sinclair Executive]], the world's first small electronic [[pocket calculator]], produced by Sir [[Clive Sinclair]] (born 1940). * 1979: The first [[laptop computer]], the [[GRiD Compass]], designed by [[Bill Moggridge]] (1943–2012). * 1979: [[Digital audio player]] (MP3 Player) invented by [[Kane Kramer]] (born 1956). K. Greye Software|J. K. Greye]] and programmed by [[Malcolm Evans (computer programmer)|Malcolm Evans]] (b. 1944). * 1984: The world's first [[pocket computer]], the ([[Psion Organiser]]), launched by London-based [[Psion (computers)|Psion]] PLC. * 1984: ''[[Elite (video game)|Elite]]'', the world's first [[computer game]] with [[3D graphics]], developed by [[David Braben]] (born 1964) and [[Ian Bell (programmer)|Ian Bell]] (born 1962). * 1985: [[ARM architecture]] introduced by [[Cambridge]] computer manufacturer [[Acorn Computers]]; the ARM CPU design is the [[microprocessor]] architecture of 98% of [[mobile phone]]s and every [[smartphone]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/ARMed-for-the-living-room/2100-1006_3-6056729.html|title=ARMed for the living room|publisher=CNET News|author=Tom Krazit|date=April 3, 2006|accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref> * 1989: [[World Wide Web]] invented by Sir [[Tim Berners-Lee]] (born 1955).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.w3.org/People/Berners-Lee/FAQ |title=Frequently asked questions by the Press – Tim BL}}</ref> * 1989: [[HTTP]] [[application protocol]] and [[HTML]] [[markup language]] developed by Sir [[Tim Berners-Lee]] (born 1955). * 1989: Launch of the first PC-compatible [[palmtop]] computer, the ([[Atari Portfolio]]), designed by [[Ian Cullimore]]. * 1989: First [[touchpad]] pointing device developed for London-based [[Psion (computers)|Psion]] PLC's Psion MC 200/400/600/WORD Series. * 1990: The world's first [[web browser]] invented by Sir [[Tim Berners-Lee]] (born 1955). ==Industrial processes== [[File:IKBrunelChains.jpg|thumb|160px|[[Isambard Kingdom Brunel]], a pioneer of the [[Industrial Revolution]]]] * 1740: [[Crucible steel|English crucible steel]] developed by [[Benjamin Huntsman]] (1704–1776). * 1743: [[Sheffield plate]], a layered combination of [[silver]] and [[copper]], invented by [[Thomas Boulsover]] (1705–1788). * 1746: The [[lead chamber process]], for producing [[sulfuric acid]] in large quantities, invented by [[John Roebuck]] (1718–1794). * c. 1760-c. 1840: Pioneers of the [[Industrial Revolution]] – [[Isambard Kingdom Brunel]] (1806–1859); [[Abraham Darby I]] (1678–1717); [[Abraham Darby II]] (1711–1763); [[Abraham Darby III]] (1750–1789); [[Robert Forester Mushet]] (1811–1891). * 1769: The [[water frame]], a water-powered [[spinning frame]], invented by [[Richard Arkwright]] (1732–1792). * c. 1770: [[Coade stone]], a high quality [[stoneware]], created by [[Eleanor Coade]] (1733–1821). * 1784–1789: [[Power loom]] developed by [[Edmund Cartwright]] (1743–1823). * 1795: [[Hydraulic press]] invented by [[Joseph Bramah]] (1748–1814). * 1820: The Rubber Masticator, a machine for recycling rubber, invented by [[Thomas Hancock (inventor)|Thomas Hancock]] (1786–1865). * 1824: [[Portland cement]] patented by [[Joseph Aspdin]] (1778–1855). * 1840: [[Electroplating]] process patented by [[George Elkington]] (1801–1865). * 1843: [[Vulcanisation]] of [[rubber]], a process for making natural rubber more durable, patented by [[Thomas Hancock (inventor)|Thomas Hancock]] (1786–1865). * 1850: The [[Parkes process]], for removing [[silver]] from [[lead]] during the production of [[bullion]], invented by [[Alexander Parkes]] (1813–1890). * 1850–1855: Steel production [[Bessemer process]] developed by [[Henry Bessemer]] (1813–1898). * 1862: First man-made [[plastic]] – [[Nitrocellulose]], branded [[Parkesine]] – invented by [[Alexander Parkes]] (1813–1890). * 1912: [[Stainless steel]] invented by [[Harry Brearley]] (1871–1948). * 1933: First industrially practical [[polythene]] discovered by accident in 1933 by Eric Fawcett and Reginald Gibson in [[Northwich]]. * 1952: The [[float glass]] process, for the manufacture of high-quality flat glass, invented by [[Alastair Pilkington]] (1920–1995). * 1950s: The [[Wilson Yarn Clearer]] developed by inventor Peter Wilson (dates not known). * 2001: [[Self-cleaning glass]] is developed by [[Pilkington]].
==Medicine== [[File:Eduard Jenner.jpg|thumb|160px|[[Edward Jenner]], invented the [[smallpox vaccine]], the first successful vaccine to be developed, in 1798]] * Anglo-Saxon times: The earliest [[pharmacopoeia]] in English ([[Cotton Vitellius]], MS C. iii).<ref>{{cite journal|pmc=1044312 |title=The Old English illustrated pharmacopoeia: British Library Cotton Vitellius CIII |page=433 |volume=44 |issue=3 |journal=Medical History|doi=10.1017/S0025727300066989}}</ref> * 1628: First correct description of [[Circulatory system|circulation]] of the [[blood]] in ''[[Exercitatio Anatomica de Motu Cordis et Sanguinis in Animalibus|De Motu Cordis]]'' by [[William Harvey]] (1578–1657).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/harvey_william.shtml|publisher=BBC|title=William Harvey (1578 – 1657)|accessdate=2010-12-06}}</ref> * 18th century: Invention of [[surgical forceps]] attributed to [[Stephen Hales]] (1677–1761).<ref name="RPC 1">Scientific American inventions and discoveries By Rodney P. Carlisle</ref> * c. 1711: First [[blood pressure]] measurement and [[History of invasive and interventional cardiology|first cardiac catheterisation]] by [[Stephen Hales]] (1677–1761).<ref>{{cite journal |author=West JB |title=Stephen Hales: neglected respiratory physiologist |journal=Journal of Applied Physiology |volume=57 |issue=3 |pages=635–9 |date=September 1984 |pmid=6386767}}</ref> * 1763: [[Aspirin]]'s active ingredient discovered by [[Edward Stone (clergyman)|Edward Stone]] (1702–1768). * 1770s: Isolation of [[fibrin]], a key protein in the blood [[coagulation]] process; investigation of the structure of the [[lymphatic system]]; and description of [[red blood cell]]s by surgeon [[William Hewson (surgeon)|William Hewson]] (1739–1774), so-called "father of [[haematology]]". * 1775: First demonstration that a [[cancer]] may be caused by an environmental [[carcinogen]] by [[Percivall Pott]] (1714–1788), also a founding father of [[orthopedy]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Androutsos G |title=The outstanding British surgeon Percivall Pott (1714–1789) and the first description of an occupational cancer |journal=Journal of the Balkan Union of Oncology |volume=11 |issue=4 |pages=533–9 |year=2006 |pmid=17309190}}</ref> * 1794: [[Colour blindness]] first described in a paper titled "Extraordinary facts relating to the vision of colours" by [[John Dalton]] (1766–1844).<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Dalton | first1 = J | year = 1798 | title = Extraordinary facts relating to the vision of colours: with observations | url = | journal = Memoirs of the Literary and Philosophical Society of Manchester | volume = 5 | issue = | pages = 28–45 }}</ref> * 1798: [[Smallpox vaccine]], the first successful vaccine to be developed, invented by [[Edward Jenner]] (1749–1823); in so doing, Jenner is said to have "saved more lives [. . .] than were lost in all the wars of mankind since the beginning of recorded history."<ref>{{Cite book |title=Edward Jenner, the Cheltenham years, 1795–1823 |last=Saunders|first=Paul|year=1982|publisher=University Press of New England|isbn=978-0-87451-215-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Conqueror of smallpox: Dr. Edward Jenner|last=Levine|first=Israel E.|year=1960|publisher=Messner|isbn=978-0-671-63888-7}}</ref> * 1800: [[Anaesthetic]] properties of [[nitrous oxide]] (entonox/"laughing gas") discovered by [[Humphry Davy]] (1778–1829).<ref>Morris Fishbein, M.D., ed (1976). "Anesthesia". The New Illustrated Medical and Health Encyclopedia. 1 (Home Library Edition ed.). New York, N.Y. 10016: H. S. Stuttman Co. pp. 89</ref> * 1817: First description of (what would come to be called) [[Parkinson's disease]] in "An Essay on the Shaking Palsy" by [[James Parkinson]] (1755–1824).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parkinsons.org.uk/about_parkinsons/what_is_parkinsons/dr_james_parkinson.aspx|title=Dr James Parkinson|publisher=Parkinson's Disease Society of the United Kingdom|accessdate=2010-12-06}}</ref> * 1818 or 1829: First successful [[blood transfusion]] performed by [[James Blundell (physician)|James Blundell]] (1791–1878).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjhm.co.uk/cgi-bin/go.pl/library/abstract.html?uid=24500|title=James Blundell, pioneer of blood transfusion|publisher=British Journal of Hospital Medicine|author=Professor Harold Ellis|date=August 2007|accessdate=2010-12-06}}</ref> * 1819: First accurate description of [[hay fever]] by [[John Bostock (physician)|John Bostock]] (1773–1846).<ref>{{cite web|title=The History of Allergy |publisher=Auckland Allergy Clinic |date=December 2001 |url=http://www.allergyclinic.co.nz/guides/39.html |accessdate=2008-11-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081014035353/http://www.allergyclinic.co.nz/guides/39.html |archivedate=2008-10-14 |df= }}</ref> * 1847: [[Ophthalmoscope]] conceived by [[Charles Babbage]] (1791–1871).<ref name="RPC 1"/> * 1850s: Location of the source of [[cholera]] by pioneer of [[anaesthesia]] and "father of [[epidemiology]]" [[John Snow (physician)|John Snow]] (1813–1858).<ref name="bbc_johnsnow"/> * 1850s: [[General anaesthetic]] pioneered by Englishman [[John Snow (physician)|John Snow]] (1813–1858) and Scotsman [[James Young Simpson]].<ref name="bbc_johnsnow">{{cite web | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/snow_john.shtml|publisher=BBC|title=John Snow (1813 – 1858)|accessdate=2010-12-06}}</ref> * 1850s onwards: Treatment of [[epilepsy]] pioneered by [[Edward Henry Sieveking]] (1816–1904). * 1858: First publication of ''[[Gray's Anatomy]]'', widely regarded as the first complete human-anatomy textbook, by [[Henry Gray]] (1827–1861). [[File:Florence Nightingale.jpg|thumb|160px|[[Florence Nightingale]], pioneered modern [[nursing]], from 1860 onwards]] * 1860 onwards: Modern [[nursing]] pioneered by [[Florence Nightingale]] (1820–1910). * 1867: [[Antiseptic|Antisepsis in surgery]] invented by [[Joseph Lister, 1st Baron Lister|Joseph Lister]] (1827–1912). * 1867: [[Clinical thermometer]] devised by [[Thomas Clifford Allbutt]] (1836–1925).<ref>"1866." The People's Chronology. Ed. Jason M. Everett. Thomson Gale, 2006. eNotes.com. 2006. 13 May 2007 <{{cite web |url=http://history.enotes.com/peoples-chronology/year-1866/medicine |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-05-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20071012053215/http://history.enotes.com/peoples-chronology/year-1866/medicine |archivedate=2007-10-12 |df= }}></ref> * 1887: First practical [[Electrocardiography|ECG]] machine invented by [[Augustus Desiré Waller|Augustus Waller]] of [[St Mary's Hospital (London)|St Mary's Hospital]] in [[London]].<ref>{{cite journal | author = Waller AD | title = A demonstration on man of electromotive changes accompanying the heart's beat | journal = J Physiol | volume = 8 | issue = 5 | pages = 229–34 | year = 1887 | pmid = 16991463 | pmc = 1485094 | doi=10.1113/jphysiol.1887.sp000257}}</ref> * 1898: The [[mosquito]] identified as the carrier of [[malaria]] by Sir [[Ronald Ross]] (1857–1932). * 1901: Amino acid [[Tryptophan]] discovered by [[Frederick Gowland Hopkins]] (1861–1947). * 1902: First typhoid vaccine developed by [[Almroth Wright]] (1861–1947).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www1.imperial.ac.uk/medicine/news/p71909/|title=The life and work of Sir Almroth Wright honoured in Centenary lecture|publisher=Imperial College London|date=19 September 2007|accessdate=2010-12-06|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120329115711/http://www1.imperial.ac.uk/medicine/news/p71909/|archivedate=29 March 2012|df=}}</ref> * 1912: [[Vitamin]]s discovered by [[Frederick Gowland Hopkins]] (1861–1947). * 1915: [[Acetylcholine]] (ACh) identified by Sir [[Henry Hallett Dale]] (1875–1968) for its action on heart tissue. * 1937 onwards: [[Protein crystallography]] developed by [[Dorothy Crowfoot Hodgkin]] (1910–1994); Hodgkin solved the structures of [[cholesterol]] (1937), [[penicillin]] (1946), and [[vitamin B12]] (1956), for which she was awarded the [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry]] in 1964; in 1969, she succeeded in solving the structure of [[insulin]], on which she worked for over thirty years.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Crowfoot Hodgkin D|authorlink=Dorothy Crowfoot Hodgkin|date = 1935|title=X-ray Single Crystal Photographs of Insulin|journal=Nature|volume=135|pages=591–592|doi=10.1038/135591a0|issue=3415|bibcode = 1935Natur.135..591C }}</ref> * 1937: Discovery of the [[Citric acid cycle]] ("Krebs Cycle") by German-born ([[Naturalization|naturalised]]) British physician and biochemist [[Hans Adolf Krebs]] (1900–1981) at the [[University of Sheffield]]. * 1940s: Groundbreaking research on the use of [[penicillin]] in the treatment of [[venereal disease]] carried out in London by [[Jack Suchet]] (1908–2001) with Scottish scientist [[Sir Alexander Fleming]]. * 1941: Crucial first steps in the mass production of [[penicillin]] made by [[Norman Heatley]] (1911–2004). * 1949: [[Diagnostic ultrasound]] first used to assess the thickness of bowel tissue by English-born physicist [[John J. Wild]] (1914–2009), so-called "father of medical ultrasound".<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/bmj.b4428 |title=John Wild |year=2009 |last1=Watts |first1=G. |journal=BMJ |volume=339 |pages=b4428}}</ref> * 1949–1950: Artificial [[intraocular lens]] transplant surgery for [[cataract]] patients developed by [[Harold Ridley (ophthalmologist)|Harold Ridley]] (1906–2001).<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/sir-harold-ridley-729214.html|publisher=The Independent|accessdate=2010-12-06|title=Sir Harold Ridley|location=London|date=2001-06-13}}</ref> * Late 1950s: [[Peak flow meter|Peak Flow Meter]] invented by [[Martin Wright (bioengineer)|Martin Wright]] (1912–2001), also the creator of the [[Syringe driver|Syringe Driver]]. * 1960 onwards: The [[hip replacement]] operation (in which a [[stainless steel]] stem and 22mm head fit into a [[polymer]] socket and both parts are fixed into position by [[Poly(methyl methacrylate)|PMMA]] cement) pioneered by [[John Charnley]] (1911–1982). * 1960s: First use of [[sodium cromoglycate]] for [[asthma]] [[Preventive healthcare|prophylaxis]] associated with [[Roger Altounyan]] (1922–1987).<ref>{{cite journal |author=Orr, T. S. C. |title=Roger Altounyan: the man and his work |journal=Respiratory Medicine |volume=83 |issue=Supplement |pages=3–6 |date=May 1989 |pmid= |doi=10.1016/s0954-6111(89)80243-4}}</ref> * 1967 onwards: [[Computed Tomography]] and first commercial [[CT scan]]ner invented by Sir [[Godfrey Hounsfield]] (1919–2004) in [[Hayes, Hillingdon|Hayes, Middlesex]], at [[EMI]] Central Research Laboratories. * 1969–1978: Development of [[in vitro fertilisation]] (IVF) by [[Patrick Christopher Steptoe]] (1913–1988) and [[Robert Geoffrey Edwards]] (1925–2013).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/7505635.stm|title=30th birthday for first IVF baby|publisher=BBC News|date=14 July 2008|accessdate=2010-12-06|first=Fergus|last=Walsh}}</ref> * Late 1970s: [[Echo-planar imaging]] (EPI) technique, a contribution to the development of [[magnetic resonance imaging]] (MRI), developed by Sir [[Peter Mansfield]] (born 1933).<ref>{{cite journal |author=Mansfield P., Grannell, P. |date=1975 |title=Diffraction and microscopy in solids and liquids by NMR |journal=Physical Review B |volume=12 |number=9 |pages=3618–3634 |doi= 10.1103/physrevb.12.3618 |bibcode=1975PhRvB..12.3618M}}</ref> * 1980: Potential of [[hematopoietic stem cell transplantation]] in treating a wide range of genetic diseases, among other breakthroughs, discovered by [[John Raymond Hobbs]] (1929–2008).<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2008/sep/05/medicalresearch.health|title=John Hobbs|publisher=The Guardian|date=5 September 2008|accessdate=2010-12-06|location=London|first1=Pamela|last1=Riches|first2=Colin|last2=Steward}}</ref> * 1981: Discovery of how to [[culture]] [[embryonic stem cells]] credited to England-born biologist [[Martin Evans]] (born 1941). * 1993: [[Viagra]] (a.k.a. Sildenafil – compound UK-92,480) synthesised by a group of pharmaceutical chemists working at Pfizer's [[Sandwich, Kent]] research facility in England. The press identified Peter Dunn and Albert Wood as the inventors of the drug; only Andrew Bell, David Brown and Nicholas Terrett are listed on the original composition of matter patent.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.google.com/patents/US5250534?dq=5,250,534&hl=en&sa=X&ei=hNNvU_eTFdTdoATokYL4DA&ved=0CDcQ6AEwAA |title=Pyrazolopyrimidinone antianginal agents US 5250534 A |date=1993 |work=Patents |publisher=Google |accessdate=4 January 2016}}</ref> * 2009: First baby genetically selected to be free of a [[breast cancer]] born at [[University College Hospital]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Breast cancer gene-free baby born |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/7819651.stm |newspaper=BBC News |date=9 January 2009 |accessdate=4 January 2016}}</ref> * 2014: The "Mom incubator", an [[Inflatable]] [[Neonatal intensive care unit#Incubator|incubator]] for reducing [[mortality rate]]s in [[Preterm birth|premature babies]], invented by James Roberts.<ref>{{cite news |title=Inflatable incubator aims to help save premature babies |url=https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2014/dec/25/inflatable-incubator-premature-babies |newspaper=The Guardian |date=25 December 2014 |accessdate=4 January 2016}}</ref>
==Military== [[File:The Invention of the Machine Gun; Hiram Maxim Q81725.jpg|thumb|Sir [[Hiram Maxim]], invented the [[machine gun]] in 1884]] * 1718: The [[Puckle Gun]] or ''Defence Gun'', a multi-shot gun mounted on a tripod, invented by [[James Puckle]] (1667–1724). * 1784: [[Shrapnel shell]], an anti-personnel artillery munition, developed by [[Henry Shrapnel]] (1761–1842). * 1804: The [[Congreve rocket]], a weapon, invented by Sir [[William Congreve (inventor)|William Congreve]] (1772–1828). * 1830s: The [[Fuse (explosives)|safety fuse]] invented by [[William Bickford (1774–1834)|William Bickford]] (1774–1834). * 1854: The [[Whitworth rifle]], often called the "sharpshooter" because of its accuracy and considered one of the earliest examples of a [[sniper rifle]], invented by Sir [[Joseph Whitworth]] (1803–1887).<ref>{{cite book | last = Atkinson | first = Norman | authorlink = Norman Atkinson | title = Sir Joseph Whitworth: "the World's Best Mechanician" | publisher = [[Sutton Publishing|Sutton Publishing Limited]] | year = 1996 | location = Gloucester|isbn = 0-7509-1211-1}}</ref><ref>Kilburn, Terence (1987) ''Joseph Whitworth: Toolmaker'', two editions, 1987 and 2002</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Lea | first = F. C. | title = Sir Joseph Whitworth: a Pioneer of Mechanical Engineering | publisher = Longmans, Green | year = 1946 | location = London}}</ref> * 1854–1857: The [[Armstrong Gun]], a uniquely designed field and heavy gun, developed by Sir [[William Armstrong, 1st Baron Armstrong|William Armstrong]] (1810–1900). * 1866: First effective self-propelled naval [[torpedo]] invented by [[Robert Whitehead]] (1823–1905). * 1875: The side by side [[boxlock action]], commonly used in [[double barreled shotgun]]s, invented by William Anson and John Deeley for the [[Westley Richards]] company of [[Birmingham]]. * 1884: The [[Maxim gun]], the first self-powered [[machine gun]] invented by Sir [[Hiram Maxim]] (1840–1916); American-born, Maxim moved from the United States to England in 1881, becoming a ([[Naturalization|naturalised]]) [[British subject]]. The Maxim gun was financed by Albert Vickers of [[Vickers Limited]] and produced in [[Hatton Garden]], [[London]]. It has been called "the weapon most associated with British imperial conquest".<ref>{{Citation |last=Gilbert |first=Martin |title=A History of the Twentieth Century: Volume One; 1900–1933 |publisher=William Morrow and Company |place=New York |page=11 |year=1997 |edition=1st US |isbn=0-688-10064-3}}</ref> * 1891: [[Cordite]], first of the "[[smokeless powder]]s" which came into general use towards the end of the 19th century, invented by Englishman [[Frederick Abel]] (1827–1902) and Scot [[James Dewar]]. * 1901: [[Bullpup]] firearm configuration first used in the [[Thorneycroft carbine]] rifle, developed by an English gunsmith as patent No. 14,622 of July 18, 1901. * 1906: The [[Dreadnought]] battleship, the predominant type of battleship in the early 20th century, credited to [[First Sea Lord]] Admiral [[John Fisher, 1st Baron Fisher|John "Jackie" Fisher]] (1841–1920). [[File:The Royal Navy Before the First World War Q38712.jpg|thumb|[[HMS Dreadnought (1906)|HMS Dreadnought]], 1906]] * 1914: First operational [[fighter aircraft]], the [[Vickers F.B.5]] (a.k.a. th "Gunbus"), developed from a design by [[Archibald Low]] (1888–1956). * 1916: The [[tank]] developed and first used in combat by the British during [[Tanks in World War I|World War I]] as a means to break the deadlock of trench warfare.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-25109879|title=World War One: The tank's secret Lincoln origins|work=BBC News|accessdate=1 April 2015}}</ref> Key co-inventors include Major [[Walter Gordon Wilson]] (1874–1957) and Sir [[William Tritton]] (1875–1946). * 1916: The first effective [[depth charge]], an [[anti-submarine warfare]] weapon, developed from a design by Herbert Taylor at the RN Torpedo and Mine School, [[HMS Vernon (shore establishment)|HMS ''Vernon'']]. * 1916: The [[Livens Projector]], a weapon, created by [[William Howard Livens]] (1889–1964).<ref>[[War Office]] (1940) Operations. Part V. Use of Gas in the Field. Military Training Pamphlet No. 23.</ref> * 1917: [[Dazzle camouflage]] created by [[Norman Wilkinson (artist)|Norman Wilkinson]] (1878–1971). * 1917: [[ASDIC]] active [[sonar]], the first practical underwater active sound-detection apparatus, developed by Canadian physicist [[Robert William Boyle]] and English physicist [[Albert Beaumont Wood]] (1890–1964). * 1940s: [[High-explosive squash head]], a type of ammunition, invented by Sir [[Charles Dennistoun Burney]] (1888–1968). * 1941: The [[Fairbairn-Sykes fighting knife]] invented by [[William Ewart Fairbairn]] (1885–1960) and [[Eric A. Sykes]] (1883–1945). * 1941–1942: The [[Bailey Bridge]] – a type of portable, [[Prefabrication|pre-fabricated]], [[truss]] [[bridge]] – invented by [[Donald Bailey (civil engineer)|Donald Bailey]] (1901–1985). [[Field Marshal Montgomery]] emphasised the importance of the Bailey bridge in Britain winning the war.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.btinternet.com/~ian.a.paterson/equipotheritems.htm |title=Other Equipment Used By The 7th Armoured Division |publisher=Btinternet.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100813232737/http://www.btinternet.com/~ian.a.paterson/equipotheritems.htm |archivedate=August 13, 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |editor1=Lance Day |editor2=Ian McNeil |title = Biographical Dictionary of the History of Technology| publisher = Routledge | year=1996 | isbn = 0-415-19399-0 }}</ref> * 1943: The [[bouncing bomb]] invented by [[Barnes Wallis]] (1887–1979). * 1943: [[H2S radar]] (airborne radar to aid bomb targeting) invented by [[Alan Blumlein]] (1903–1942). Blumlein died in a plane crash during a secret trial of the H2S system. * 1950: The [[Aircraft catapult|steam catapult]], a device used to launch aircraft from aircraft carriers, developed by Commander Colin C. Mitchell [[Royal Naval Reserve|RNR]]. * 1960s: [[Chobham armour]], a type of [[vehicle armour]], developed by a team headed by Gilbert Harvey<ref>{{cite book |title=The Armored Fist — New Face of War |last=Flaherty |first=Thomas H. |year=1991 |publisher=Time Life Education |location= |isbn=0809486083 |page=82}}</ref> of the [[Fighting Vehicles Research and Development Establishment|FVRDE]] at the tank research centre on [[Chobham Common]], [[Surrey]]. * 1960: [[Harrier Jump Jet]] developed by [[Hawker Aircraft]] of [[Kingston upon Thames]] following an approach by the [[Bristol Aeroplane Company]] in 1957. * Late 1970s: [[Stun grenades]] developed by the [[British Army|British Army's]] [[Special Air Service|SAS]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eliteukforces.info/special-air-service/weapons/stun-grenade.php |title=SAS – Weapons – Flash Bang | Stun Grenade |publisher=Eliteukforces.info |accessdate=2013-05-29}}</ref>
==Mining== * 1712: The [[Newcomen atmospheric engine|Newcomen Engine]] invented by [[Thomas Newcomen]] (1664–1729); from c. 1705 Newcomen was first to use a [[Beam engine]] to pump water from mines. * 1815: The [[Davy lamp]], a [[safety lamp]], invented by [[Humphry Davy]] (1778–1829). * 1815: The [[Geordie lamp]], a [[safety lamp]], invented by [[George Stephenson]] (1781–1848).
==Musical instruments== * 1695: [[Northumbrian smallpipes]] (a.k.a. Northumbrian pipes) associated with [[Northumberland]] and [[Tyne and Wear]]. * 1711: The [[Tuning fork]] invented by [[John Shore (trumpeter)|John Shore]] (c. 1662–1752). * 1798: The [[harp lute]] invented by Edward Light (c. 1747-c. 1832); Light patented the instrument in 1816.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O372394/harp-lute-light-edward/ |title=Harp-lute |publisher=[[Victoria and Albert Museum|V&A]] |accessdate=5 January 2016}}</ref> * Early 19th century: The [[Irish flute]] is not an instrument indigenous to Ireland; a key figure in its development was English inventor and flautist [[Charles Nicholson (flautist)|Charles Nicholson]] (1775–1810). * 1829: The [[concertina]] invented by [[Charles Wheatstone]] (1802–1875).<ref name="bowers_wheatstone"/> * Early 20th century: The [[theatre organ]] developed by [[Robert Hope-Jones]] (1859–1914). * 1870: Carbon microphone, invented by [[David Edward Hughes]]. * 1968: The logical [[bassoon]], an electronically controlled version of the [[bassoon]], developed by [[Giles Brindley]] (born 1926).<ref>{{cite journal |author=Brindley, Giles |title=The Logical Bassoon |journal=The Galpin Society Journal |volume=21 |issue= |pages=152–161 |date=March 1968 |pmid= |doi=10.2307/841438}}</ref>
==Photography== [[File:Thomas Wedgwood (1771-1805).jpg|thumb|160px|[[Thomas Wedgwood (photographer)|Thomas Wedgwood]], copied images chemically to permanent media by 1800]]
* Before 1800: Method of copying images chemically to permanent media devised by [[Thomas Wedgwood (photographer)|Thomas Wedgwood]] (1771–1805). * 1838: The [[Stereoscope]], a device for displaying three-dimensional images, invented by [[Charles Wheatstone]] (1802–1875).<ref name="kcl_wheatstone">{{cite web|url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/depsta/iss/library/speccoll/wheatstone.html|author=Shelley de Kock|title=Sir Charles Wheatstone and the Wheatstone Collection|accessdate=2010-12-06|publisher=King's College London}}</ref><ref name="bowers_wheatstone"/> * 1840: [[Calotype]] or ''Talbotype'' invented by [[William Fox Talbot]] (1800–1877).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/fox_talbot_william_henry.shtml|title=BBC – History – Historic Figures: William Henry Fox Talbot (1800 – 1877)|publisher=BBC|accessdate=2010-12-06}}</ref> * 1850s: The [[Collodion process]], an early photographic process, invented by [[Frederick Scott Archer]] (1813–1857).<ref name="bbc_archer">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/photoblog/2010/04/remembering_frederick_scott_archer.html|title=Remembering Frederick Scott Archer|author=Phil Coomes|publisher=BBC|date=27 April 2010|accessdate=2010-12-06}}</ref> * 1850s: The [[Ambrotype]] invented by [[Frederick Scott Archer]] (1813–1857)<ref name="bbc_archer"/> and Peter Wickens Fry (1795–1860). * 1861: The [[Collodion-albumen process]], an early [[dry plate]] process, invented by Joseph Sidebotham (father of [[Joseph Watson Sidebotham]]). * 1871: The [[dry plate]] process, the first economically successful and durable photographic medium, invented by [[Richard Leach Maddox]] (1816–1902). * 1878: ''The Horse in Motion'' or ''[[Sallie Gardner at a Gallop]]'', a precursor to the development of [[Film|motion picture]]s, created by [[Eadweard Muybridge]] (1830–1904). * 1879: The [[Zoopraxiscope]], which may be considered the first [[movie projector]], created by [[Eadweard Muybridge]] (1830–1904). * 1880s: Method of intensifying [[Photographic plate|plate]]s with [[Mercury(II) iodide|mercuric iodide]] devised by [[B. J. Edwards]] (1838–1914); Edwards pioneered also the construction and design of instantaneous [[Shutter (photography)|shutter]]s. * 1887: [[Celluloid]] [[Film|motion pictures]] created by [[William Friese-Greene]] (1855–1921). * 1906: [[Kinemacolor]], the first successful colour [[motion picture]] process, invented by [[George Albert Smith (inventor)|George Albert Smith]] (1864–1959).
==Publishing firsts== [[File:Myles Coverdale.jpg|thumb|140px|[[Myles Coverdale]], produced first complete printed English [[Bible]], 1535]] * 1475: First book printed in the English language, ''[[Recuyell of the Historyes of Troye]]'', by [[William Caxton]] (c. 1422–c. 1491); eighteen copies survive. * 1534: [[Cambridge University Press]] granted [[letters patent]] by [[Henry VIII]]; continuous operation since makes it the world's oldest publisher and printer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/2000/oldest-printing-and-publishing-house |title=Oldest printing and publishing house |publisher=Guinnessworldrecords.com |date=2002-01-22 |accessdate=2012-03-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title = Cambridge University Press, 1583–1984 |first= Michael |last = Black |pages= 328–9 |year = 1984 |isbn = 978-0-521-66497-4}}</ref> * 1535: First complete printed translation of the [[Bible]] into English produced by [[Myles Coverdale]] (1488–1569).<ref name="BritLib">{{cite web|last1=Anon|title=Early Printed Bibles – in English – 1535–1610|url=http://www.bl.uk/reshelp/findhelprestype/prbooks/earprintbib/earlyprintbib15351610/earlyprintedbibleseng1535.html|website=British Library – Help for Researchers – Coverdale Bible|publisher=The British Library Board|accessdate=4 March 2015}}</ref> * 1665: ''[[Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society|Philosophical Transactions]]'', the first journal exclusively devoted to science, established by the [[Royal Society]] of London; it is also the world's longest-running scientific journal.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Oldenburg | first1 = Henry| authorlink = Henry Oldenburg| doi = 10.1098/rstl.1665.0001 | title = Epistle Dedicatory | journal = [[Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society]]| volume = 1 | pages = 0–0 | year = 1665 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref> * British Raj period: the first definite map of [[India]] drawn by English [[cartographers]]. * Mid-19th century: First noted [[journal club]] by English surgeon [[James Paget|Sir James Paget]] (1814–1899); recalling in his memoirs time spent at [[St. Bartholomew's Hospital]] in London, Paget describes "a kind of club [. . .] a small room over a baker's shop near the Hospital-gate where we could sit and read the [[Scientific journal|journals]]."<ref>{{cite web|last=Esisi|first= Martina|title=Journal clubs - BMJ Careers|date= 13 October 2007|accessdate=9 January 2010|url=http://careers.bmj.com/careers/advice/view-article.html?id=2631#ref2}}</ref> * 1893: [[Benjamin Daydon Jackson]] prepares the first volume of ''[[Index Kewensis]]'', first publication aiming to register all [[botanical names]] for [[seed plant]]s at the rank of [[species]] and [[Genus|genera]].
==Science==
===Physics=== [[File:Sir Isaac Newton 1702.jpg|thumb|160px|Sir [[Isaac Newton]], a giant of the [[scientific revolution]]]] [[File:Michael Faraday. Photograph. Wellcome V0017866.jpg|thumb|160px|[[Michael Faraday]], made key discoveries relating to [[electric current|electricity]], 1820s–1840s]] [[File:James Chadwick.jpg|thumb|160px|Sir [[James Chadwick]], awarded 1935 [[Nobel Prize in Physics]] for his discovery of the [[neutron]] in 1932]] * 1600: Recognition that the earth was a giant magnet, by [[William Gilbert (astronomer)|William Gilbert]] (1544–1603) in his six-book work ''[[De Magnete]]''; ''De Magnete'' was known all over Europe, and was almost certainly an influence on [[Galileo Galilei|Galileo]]. * 1660: [[Hooke's Law]] (equation describing elasticity) proposed by [[Robert Hooke]] (1635–1703).<ref name="dicteng"/> * 1666–1675: Theories on [[optics]] proposed by Sir [[Isaac Newton]] (1642–1726/7); Newton published ''[[Opticks]]'' in 1704. * 1687: Law of [[Newton's law of universal gravitation|universal gravitation]] formulated in the ''[[Philosophiæ Naturalis Principia Mathematica|Principia]]'' by Sir [[Isaac Newton]] (1642–1726/7). * 1687: [[Newton's laws of motion]] formulated in the ''[[Philosophiæ Naturalis Principia Mathematica|Principia]]''. * 1800: [[Infrared#Human history|Infrared]] radiation discovered by Sir [[William Herschel]] (1738–1822). * 1802: Theory on physiological basis of [[Color vision|colour vision]] proposed by [[Thomas Young (scientist)|Thomas Young]] (1773–1829). * 1803–1807: Evidence for a [[wave theory of light]] discovered by [[Thomas Young (scientist)|Thomas Young]] (1773–1829). * 1823: [[Electromagnet]] invented by [[William Sturgeon]] (1783–1850).<ref name="windelspecht"/> * 1831: Discovery that [[electric current]] could be generated by altering [[magnetic field]]s (the principle underlying modern [[Electricity generation|power generation]]) by [[Michael Faraday]] (1791–1867).<ref name="rigb_faraday"/> * 1845: Proposition that [[light]] and [[electromagnetism]] are related by [[Michael Faraday]] (1791–1867).<ref name="rigb_faraday"/> * 1845–1847: Demonstration that [[electric circuit]]s obey the law of the conservation of energy and that [[electricity]] is a form of energy ([[First Law of Thermodynamics]]) by [[James Prescott Joule|James Joule]] (1818–1889); the unit of energy the [[Joule]] is named after him. * 1871 and 1885: Discovery of the phenomenon [[Rayleigh scattering]] (which can be used to explain why the sky is blue), and prediction of the existence of [[surface waves]] by [[John Strutt, 3rd Baron Rayleigh]] (1842–1919).<ref name=prixnobel>{{cite web | year=1904| title=Lord Rayleigh: The Nobel Prize in Physics 1904| url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/physics/laureates/1904/strutt-bio.html| publisher=[[The Nobel Foundation]]| accessdate=2010-05-05}}</ref> * 1897: Discovery of the [[electron]] by [[J. J. Thomson]] (1856–1940). * 1911: Discovery of the [[Rutherford model]] of the [[Atom]] by [[Ernest Rutherford]] (1871–1937). * 1912: Invention of the [[mass spectrometer]] by [[J. J. Thomson]] (1856–1940). * 1912: [[Bragg's law]] and the field of [[X-ray crystallography]], an important tool for elucidating the [[crystal structure]] of substances, discovered by [[William Henry Bragg]] (1862–1942) and [[William Lawrence Bragg]] (1890–1971).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/physics/laureates/1915/present.html |title=The Nobel Prize in Physics 1915 William Bragg, Lawrence Bragg}}</ref> * 1913: Discovery of [[isotopes]] by [[J. J. Thomson]] (1856–1940). * 1917: Discovery of the [[Proton]] by [[Ernest Rutherford]] (1871–1937). * 1924: [[Edward Victor Appleton]] awarded Nobel Prize in Physics in 1947 for proving the existence of the [[ionosphere]] during experiments carried out in 1924. * 1928: Existence of [[antimatter]] predicted by [[Paul Dirac]] (1902–1984); Dirac made major contributions to the development of [[quantum mechanics]]. * 1932: [[Splitting the atom]], a fully artificial nuclear reaction and nuclear transmutation, first achieved by English physicist [[John Cockcroft]] (1897–1967) and Ireland's [[Ernest Walton]]. * 1932: Discovery of the [[Neutron]] by [[James Chadwick]] (1891–1974). * 1935: Possibility of [[Radar]] first proven in the "[[Daventry]] experiment" by Englishman [[Arnold Frederic Wilkins]] (1907–1985) and Scot [[Robert Watson-Watt]]. * 1947: [[Holography]] invented in Rugby, England by Hungarian-British [[Dennis Gabor]] (1900–1979; fled from [[Nazi Germany]] in 1933). The medium was improved by [[Nicholas J. Phillips]] (1933–2009), who made it possible to record multi-colour reflection holograms. * 1947: Discovery of the [[pion]] (pi-[[meson]]) by [[Cecil Frank Powell]] (1903–1969). * 1964: The [[Higgs boson]], an [[elementary particle]] implied by the [[Higgs mechanism|Higgs field]], proposed by [[Peter Higgs]] (born 1929) and others to explain why fundamental particles (which are theoretically [[Weightlessness|weightless]]) might have acquired [[mass]] after their formation in the [[Big Bang]]. * 1974: [[Hawking radiation]] predicted by [[Stephen Hawking]] (1942–2018).

===Biology=== [[File:Charles Darwin photograph by Elliott and Fry, circa 1875.jpg|thumb|140px|[[Charles Darwin]]'s theory of [[evolution]] published in 1859]] * 1665: [[Cell biology]] originated by [[Robert Hooke]] (1635–1703), who discovered the first [[Cell (biology)|cell]]s in the course of describing the microscopic compartments within cork.<ref name="windelspecht">{{cite book|title=Groundbreaking Scientific Experiments, Inventions, and Discoveries of the 19th Century|author=Windelspecht, Michael|publisher=Greenwood Press|year=2003|isbn=978-0-313-31969-3}}</ref> * Early 19th century: the first recognition of what fossils were by [[Mary Anning]]. * 1839: The identification and discovery of 150 [[mosses]], [[lichens]], [[liverworts]], [[flowering plants]] and [[algae]] on the [[Kerguelen Islands]] by [[botanist]] [[Joseph Dalton Hooker]]. He later said of his gatherings "many of my best little lichens were gathered by hammering out the turfs or sitting on them till they thawed." * 1855: The discovery of the first [[coal ball]] by [[Joseph Dalton Hooker]] who later on with partner William Binney made the first scientific description of coal balls. * 1859: Theories of [[evolution]] by [[natural selection]] and [[sexual selection]] set out in ''[[On the Origin of Species]]'' by [[Charles Darwin]] (1809–1882). * 1883: The practice of [[Eugenics]] developed by Sir [[Francis Galton]] (1822–1911), applying his half-cousin [[Charles Darwin]]'s theory of [[evolution]] to humans.<ref>{{cite book|title=DNA: The Secret of Life|author1=Watson, James D.|author2=Berry, Andrew |year=2009 |publisher=Knopf |url=https://www.amazon.com/DNA-The-Secret-Life-ebook/dp/B001PSEQAG}}</ref> * 1953: Double-helix structure of [[DNA]] determined by Englishman [[Francis Crick]] (1906–2004)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/medicine/laureates/1962/crick-bio.html|title=Francis Crick's 1962 Biography from the Nobel foundation}}</ref> and American [[James D. Watson|James Watson]]. Crick was a pioneer in the field of [[molecular biology]]. * 1958: the first cloning of an animal, a frog using intact [[Cell nucleus|nuclei]] from the somatic cells of a Xenopus tadpole by Sir [[John Gurdon]]. * 1950 onward: the pioneering of the use of Xenopus eggs to translate microinjected messenger RNA molecules by Sir [[John Gurdon]] and fellow researchers, a technique which has been widely used to identify the proteins encoded and to study their function. * 1960 onwards: Pioneering observation-based research into the behaviour of [[chimpanzees]] (our closest relatives in the animal kingdom) conducted by [[Jane Goodall]] (born 1934). * 1977: [[DNA sequencing]] by chain termination developed by [[Frederick Sanger]] (1918–2013).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/chemistry/laureates/1958/sanger-bio.html|title=Frederick Sanger}}</ref> Sanger won the [[Nobel Prize for Chemistry]] twice. * 1977: Discovery of [[introns]] in [[eukaryotic]] [[DNA]] and the mechanism of [[Alternative splicing|gene-splicing]] by [[Richard J. Roberts]] (born 1943).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/medicine/laureates/1993/roberts-autobio.html |title=Richard J. Roberts Biography from the Nobel foundation}}</ref> * 1996: [[Dolly the Sheep]] born as a result of [[Nuclear transfer]], a form of cloning put into practice by [[Ian Wilmut]] (born 1944) and [[Keith Campbell (biologist)|Keith Campbell]] (1954–2012). * 2016: Scientists at the British [[bio-tech]] company [[Oxitec]], in an attempt to stop the spread of [[dengue fever]] genetically engineer a 'sudden death' [[mosquito]] which after mating successfully with a wild female, any offspring produced will not survive to adulthood and the lethal gene is passed on from the female to any male they mate with and the cycle continues. 3,019,000 mosquitos were released on the [[Grand Cayman Islands]] and after three months 80% of the population of mosquitos in the target area had vanished.
===Mathematics and statistics=== [[File:Photo of George Boole standing.png|thumb|160px|[[George Boole]], whose [[Boolean algebra]] (1854) laid the foundations of the [[Information Age]]]] * 1630–1632: The [[slide rule]] invented by [[William Oughtred]] (1574–1660), developing on work by [[Edmund Gunter]] (1581–1626) and [[Edmund Wingate]] (1596–1656).<ref name="dicteng"/><ref name="oughtred.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.oughtred.org/history-new.shtml |title=The Oughtred Society: Slide Rule History |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070709072617/http://www.oughtred.org/history-new.shtml |archivedate=July 9, 2007 }}</ref> * 1631: The "x" symbol for [[multiplication]] and the abbreviations "sin" and "cos" for the [[sine]] and [[cosine]] functions devised by [[William Oughtred]] (1574–1660) in ''Clavis Mathematicae'' (The Key to Mathematics). * 1631: The symbols for "is less than" and "is greater than", along with other innovations, devised in the posthumously published [[algebra]] text ''Artis Analyticae Praxis'' by [[Thomas Harriot]] (c. 1560–1621). * 1687: [[Calculus]] developed by [[Sir Isaac Newton]] (1642–1726/7), as set out in his ''[[Philosophiæ Naturalis Principia Mathematica|Principia Mathematica]]''. * 1763 onwards: Key contributions made to the development of [[statistics]] by: [[Thomas Bayes]] (c. 1701–1761) (''[[Bayes' theorem]]''); [[Florence Nightingale]] (1820–1910) (''[[statistical graphics]]''); [[Francis Galton]] (1822–1911) (''[[standard deviation]]'', ''[[correlation]]'', ''[[regression analysis|regression]]'', ''[[questionnaire]]s''); [[Karl Pearson]] (1857–1936) (''[[Pearson product-moment correlation coefficient|correlation coefficient]]'', ''[[Pearson's chi-squared test|chi-square]]''); [[William Sealy Gosset|William Gosset]] (1876–1937) (''[[Student's t-distribution]]''); [[Ronald Fisher]] (1890–1962) (''[[Analysis of variance]]''); [[Frank Yates]] (1902–1994). * 1854: [[Boolean algebra (logic)|Boolean algebra]], the basis for [[Logic gate|digital logic]], proposed by [[George Boole]] (1815–1864). * 1876: Connection between energy, matter and the curvature of space proposed in ''[[s:On the Space-Theory of Matter]]'' by [[William Kingdon Clifford]] (1845–1879), forty years before [[Albert Einstein|Einstein]]'s [[General relativity|general theory of relativity]]. * c. 1880: The [[Venn diagram]] devised by [[John Venn]] (1834–1923). * 1884: Reformulation of [[Maxwell's equations]] into the four we know now by [[Oliver Heaviside]] (1850–1925). * 1901: Discipline of modern [[mathematical statistics]] developed by [[Karl Pearson]] (1857–1936).<ref name=year150>{{cite web|url=http://www.economics.soton.ac.uk/staff/aldrich/KP150.htm|accessdate=25 July 2008 |title=Karl Pearson sesquicentenary conference|date=3 March 2007|publisher=Royal Statistical Society}}</ref><ref>"[...] the founder of modern statistics, Karl Pearson." – Bronowski, Jacob (1978). ''The Common Sense of Science'', Harvard University Press, p. 128.</ref>
