(1706–1761).<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2LZZginzib4C&pg=PA140#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Stargazer: the life and times of the telescope|isbn=978-1-74175-383-7|author1=Watson, Fred|date=2007-10-01}}</ref> * 1781: Discovery of the planet [[Uranus]] by Sir [[William Herschel]] (1738–1822);<ref>{{cite journal |author=Mr. Herschel and Watson |title=Account of a Comet. By Mr. Herschel, F. R. S.; Communicated by Dr. Watson, Jun. of Bath, F. R. S. |journal=Phil. Trans. R. Soc. Lond. |volume=71 |pages=492–501 |year=1781 |doi=10.1098/rstl.1781.0056 |url=http://rstl.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/71/492.full.pdf+html |format=PDF |bibcode=1781RSPT...71..492H}}</ref> Herschel also discovered the moons [[Titania (moon)|Titania]] (1787), [[Oberon (moon)|Oberon]] (1787), [[Enceladus (moon)|Enceladus]] (1789), and [[Mimas (moon)|Mimas]] (1789).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/append7.html |title=Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature: Planet and Satellite Names and Discoverers}}</ref> * 1783: Existence of [[black holes]] first proposed by [[John Michell]] (1724–1793); Michell was first to suggest that [[binary stars|double stars]] might be attracted to each other (1767), and he invented the [[torsion balance]] (before 1783).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.astronomyedinburgh.org/publications/journals/39/blackholes.html|title=Black Holes – Part 1 – History|first=Alan|last=Ellis|accessdate=2011-01-20}}</ref> * 1843: Existence and position of [[Neptune]] predicted, using only mathematics, by [[John Couch Adams]] (1819–1892).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.talktalk.co.uk/reference/encyclopaedia/hutchinson/m0009726.html|title=Adams, John Quincy encyclopaedia hutchinson}} web</ref> * 1845: Nature of [[spiral galaxies]] discovered by [[William Parsons, 3rd Earl of Rosse]] (1800–1867).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://amazing-space.stsci.edu/resources/explorations//groundup/lesson/scopes/rosse/index.php|title=Spiral galaxies – William Parsons, 3rd Earl of Rosse}}</ref> * 1846: Discovery of [[Triton (moon)|Triton]] by [[William Lassell]] (1799–1880);<ref>{{cite journal|arxiv=0908.1553|title=WASP-17b: an ultra-low density planet in a probable retrograde orbit|author1=Anderson|author2=Hellier|author3=Gillon|author4=Triaud|author5=Smalley|author6=Hebb|author7=Collier Cameron|author8=Maxted|author9=Queloz|year=2009|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/709/1/159|volume=709|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|pages=159–167|bibcode=2010ApJ...709..159A}} web</ref> Lassell also discovered the moons [[Hyperion (moon)|Hyperion]] (1848), [[Ariel (moon)|Ariel]] (1851), and [[Umbriel (moon)|Umbriel]] (1851).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mikeoates.org/lassell/lassell_by_a_chapman.htm|title=William Lassell (1799–1880) and the discovery of Triton, 1846|website=Mikeoates.org|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref> * 1924: The [[Eddington limit]] – the natural limit to the [[luminosity]] of stars, or the radiation generated by accretion onto a compact object – discovered by Sir [[Arthur Stanley Eddington]] (1882–1944).<ref>{{cite journal|bibcode=2008AIPC..990..250V|title=Continuum driven winds from super-Eddington stars. A tale of two limits | doi=10.1063/1.2905555|arxiv = 0708.4207 }}</ref> * 1930s–1950s: Important contributions to the development of [[radio astronomy]] made by [[Bernard Lovell]] (1913–2012).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scienceworld.wolfram.com/biography/Lovell.html|title=Lovell, Bernard }} web</ref> * 1946–1954: Pioneering theories of [[Nucleosynthesis]] (the formation of chemical elements in stars and supernova) proposed by Sir [[Fred Hoyle]] (1915–2001); in 1949, Hoyle coined the term "[[Big Bang]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.beliefnet.com/News/Science-Religion/2001/09/Was-Life-Begun-By-Chance-Not-A-Chance.aspx?p=2|title=Sir Fred Hoyle}}</ref> * 1966 onwards: Important contributions to [[cosmology]] and (from 1973)[[quantum gravity]] made by [[Stephen Hawking]] (born 1942), especially in the context of [[black hole]]s. * 1967: [[Pulsar]]s discovered by English [[Radio astronomy|radio astronomer]] [[Antony Hewish]] (born 1924) and one of his graduate students, Northern Irish [[Jocelyn Bell Burnell|Jocelyn Bell]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Sigman DS, Kuwabara MD, Chen CH, Bruice TW |title=Nuclease activity of 1,10-phenanthroline-copper in study of protein-DNA interactions |journal=Methods in Enzymology |volume=208 |issue= |pages=414–33 |year=1991 |pmid=1779842 |doi=10.1016/0076-6879(91)08022-a}}</ref> * Late 1960s / early 1970s: [[Aperture synthesis]], used for accurate location and imaging of weak radio sources in the field of [[radio astronomy]], developed by [[Martin Ryle]] (1918–1984) and [[Antony Hewish]] (born 1924).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nobel-winners.com/Physics/antony_hewish.html|title=Antony Hewish biography}}</ref>
===Geology and meteorology=== * 1802: [[Clouds|Nomenclature system for clouds]] developed by [[meteorology]] pioneer [[Luke Howard]] (1772–1864).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rmets.org/weather/observing/luke-howard.php|title=Luke Howard and Cloud Names|publisher=Royal Meteorological Society|accessdate=2010-12-06}}</ref> * 1815: First [[geological map]] of [[Great Britain]] created by [[William Smith (geologist)|William Smith]] (1769–1839); Smith is responsible, as well, for the observation that fossils can be used to work out the relative ages of rocks and strata ([[Principle of Faunal Succession]]). * 1820: The dew-point [[hygrometer]], an instrument used for measuring the moisture content in the atmosphere, invented by [[John Frederic Daniell]] (1790–1845). * 1820s: Scientific study of [[dinosaur]]s initiated by [[Gideon Mantell]] (1790–1852). * 1861: First [[weather map]] created by [[Francis Galton]] (1822–1911).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scienceworld.wolfram.com/biography/Galton.html|title=Francis Galton (1822–1911) – from Eric Weisstein's World of Scientific Biography|first=Weisstein, Eric|last=W.|website=scienceworld.wolfram.com|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref> * 1880: The [[Seismograph]], for detecting and measuring the strength of earthquakes, invented by [[John Milne]] (1850–1913). * 1911 onwards: [[Geochronology]] pioneered by [[Arthur Holmes]] (1890–1965).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mysite.du.edu/~jcalvert/geol/holmes.htm|title=Principles of Geology|website=mysite.du.edu|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref> * 1938–1964: The [[Callendar effect]], a theory linking rising carbon dioxide concentrations in the atmosphere to global temperature ([[Global warming]]), proposed by [[Guy Stewart Callendar]] (1898–1964). [[File:Karl Pearson.jpg|thumb|160px|[[Karl Pearson]]'s ''[[The Grammar of Science|Grammar of Science]]'' (1892) influenced the young [[Albert Einstein|Einstein]]]]
===Philosophy of science=== * c. 1240s: An early framework for the [[scientific method]], based in [[Aristotle|Aristotelian]] commentaries, proposed by English statesman, scientist and Christian theologian [[Robert Grosseteste]] (c. 1175-1253).<ref>{{Cite journal|title=A. C. Crombie, Robert Grosseteste and the Origins of Experimental Science, 1100-1700, (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1971), pp. 52–60.|postscript=<!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref> * 1267: Early form of the [[scientific method]] articulated in ''[[Opus Majus]]'' by [[Roger Bacon]] (c. 1214?-c. 1292?).<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ru_E__W7euUC&pg=PA39&dq=roger-bacon+scientific-method#v=onepage&q=roger-bacon%20scientific-method&f=false |title=Introduction to Forensic Engineering|isbn=978-0-8493-8102-7|author1=Noon, Randall|year=1992}}</ref> * 1620: [[Baconian method]], a forerunner of the [[scientific method]], proposed in the ''[[Novum Organum]]'' by Sir [[Francis Bacon]] (1561–1626).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/48191/Baconian-method|title=Baconian method|work=Encyclopædia Britannica|accessdate=2010-12-06}}</ref> * 1892: Scope and method of science proposed in ''[[The Grammar of Science]]'' by [[Karl Pearson]] (1857–1936); the book was a pivotal influence on the young [[Albert Einstein]] and contained several ideas that were later to become part of his theories.<ref>Herbert, Christopher (2001). "Karl Pearson and the Human Form Divine," in ''Victorian Relativity: Radical Thought and Scientific Discovery'', Chicago University Press, pp. 145–179.</ref> [[File:Henry Maudslay.jpg|thumb|140px|[[Henry Maudslay]], a founding father of [[machine tool]] technology]]
===Scientific instruments=== * 1630–1632: The [[slide rule]] invented by [[William Oughtred]] (1574–1660), developing on work by [[Edmund Gunter]] (1581–1626) and [[Edmund Wingate]] (1596–1656).<ref name="dicteng"/><ref name="oughtred.org"/> * 1630s: The [[micrometer]] invented by [[William Gascoigne (scientist)|William Gascoigne]] (1612–1644). * 1665: Compound [[microscope]] with 30x magnification developed by [[Robert Hooke]] (1635–1703); Hooke published ''[[Micrographia]]'' in 1665. * 1668: The marine [[barometer]] invented by [[Robert Hooke]] (1635–1703).<ref name="dicteng"/> * 1677: The [[Coggeshall slide rule]], a.k.a. the carpenter's slide rule, invented by Henry Coggeshall (1623–1691).<ref>{{cite web |author=Oxford Biography Index |title=Henry Coggeshall |url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/index/5/101005815/ |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref> * 1763: Triple [[achromatic lens]] invented by [[Peter Dollond]] (1731–1820). * 1784: The [[Atwood machine]], for demonstrating the law of uniformly accelerated motion, invented by [[George Atwood]] (1745–1807). * c. 1805: First bench micrometer – the "Lord Chancellor", capable of measuring to one ten-thousandth of an inch – invented by [[Henry Maudslay]] (1771–1831), a founding father of [[machine tool]] technology.<ref>{{cite web |author=Science Museum |title=Maudslay's Lord Chancellor bench micrometer | url=http://www.sciencemuseum.org.uk/online_science/explore_our_collections/objects/index/smxg-59282 |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref> * 1833: [[Wheatstone bridge]] invented by [[Samuel Hunter Christie]] (1784–1865); improved and popularised in 1843 by [[Charles Wheatstone]] (1802–1875). * 1972: The [[Sinclair Executive]], the world's first small electronic [[pocket calculator]], invented by Sir [[Clive Sinclair]] (born 1940).
==Sport== [[File:Grace London County.jpg|thumb|160px|[[W. G. Grace]] (1848–1915); 1598 saw the earliest definite reference to [[cricket]]]] * Before 1299: [[Bowls]] or ''lawn bowls'' can be traced to 13th-century England.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/h2g2/A311482|title=h2g2 – Southampton Old Bowling Green, Southampton, England – Edited Entry|website=Bbc.co.uk|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref> The world's oldest surviving bowling green is [[Southampton Old Bowling Green]], first used in 1299. * Late 15th century: [[Rounders]] developed from an older English game known as [[stoolball]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nra-rounders.co.uk/dyncat.cfm?catid=17177|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071112065508/http://www.nra-rounders.co.uk/dyncat.cfm?catid=17177|dead-url=yes|archive-date=12 November 2007|title=National Rounders Association:- Home|date=12 November 2007|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref> * Early 16th century: Modern [[boxing]] developed from [[bare-knuckle boxing]] or ''prizefighting'', a resurfacing of [[Ancient Greek boxing]] in England. The first recorded boxing match took place on 6 January 1681 in England, arranged by [[Christopher Monck, 2nd Duke of Albemarle]] (1653–1688). * 1519: World's oldest sporting competition still running, the [[Kiplingcotes Derby]] horse-race, established; it has run annually since without a break.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lookandlearn.com/blog/8721/the-worlds-oldest-horse-race/|title=Historical articles and illustrations » Blog Archive » The world’s oldest horse race|website=Lookandlearn.com|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/history/memories/3145617.After_300_years_the_captain_is_bringing_the_Silver_Arrow_home/ |title=After 300 years, the captain is bringing the Silver Arrow home |publisher=Northern Echo |accessdate=14 January 2016 }}</ref> * 1530s: Origin of [[real tennis]] played with [[Tennis racket|rackets]], popularised by [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]].<ref>[http://www.historyoftennis.net/history_of_tennis.html The History of Tennis<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723143635/http://www.historyoftennis.net/history_of_tennis.html |date=2011-07-23 }}</ref> * 1598: The earliest definite reference to [[cricket]]; the sport may arguably be traced further back to 1301 with written evidence of a game known as ''creag'' played by [[Edward II of England|Prince Edward]], son of [[Edward I of England|Edward I (Longshanks)]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1300.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629140053/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1300.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=29 June 2011|title=From Lads to Lord's: 1300 – 1600|date=29 June 2011|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref> * [[Aunt Sally]], early 17th century. * After 1660: [[Thoroughbred]] horseracing developed in 17th- and 18th-century England; royal support from [[Charles II of England|Charles II]], a keen racegoer and owner, made horse-racing popular with the public. * 1673: Oldest non-equine competition in England, the [[Scorton Arrow]] archery tournament, established in [[Scorton, North Yorkshire|Scorton]], [[Yorkshire]].<ref>{{cite web |title = Ancient archery event tests skills for 300th time | url = http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/news/ancient-archery-event-tests-skills-for-300th-time-1-2501458 | publisher=Yorkshire Post |accessdate=2017-10-28}}</ref> * 1715: Oldest [[Rowing (sport)|rowing]] race in the world, [[Doggett's Coat and Badge]] established; the race on the [[River Thames]]) has been held every year since 1715. * 1744: Earliest description of [[baseball]] in ''[[A Little Pretty Pocket-Book]]'' by John Newbery (1713–1767); the first ''recorded game'' of "Bass-Ball" took place in 1749 in Surrey.<ref>{{cite web |author=BBC News |title=Why isn't baseball more popular in the UK? | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-23425907 |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref> [[William Bray (antiquary)|William Bray]] (1736–1832) recorded a game of baseball on Easter Monday, 1755 in [[Guildford]], [[Surrey]]; the game is considered to have been taken across the Atlantic by English emigrants.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/baseball/2800199/Major-League-Baseball-told-their-sport-was-invented-in-Surrey-not-America.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Stephen | last=Adams | title=Major League Baseball told their sport was invented in Surrey, not America | date=2008-09-11}}</ref> * Early 19th century: Modern [[field hockey]] developed in English public schools; the first club was established in 1849 in [[Blackheath, London]]. * 1820s: [[Ice hockey]], a variant of [[field hockey]], invented by British soldiers based in Canada. British soldiers and emigrants to Canada and the United States played their stick-and-ball games on the winter ice and snow; in 1825, [[John Franklin]] (1786–1847) wrote during one of his [[Arctic]] expeditions: "The game of hockey played on the ice was the morning sport" on [[Great Bear Lake]].<ref>{{cite web |author=The National Archives |title=Copy Letters: 07/09/1825 | url=http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/details/rd/5594148c-48f2-4f64-a352-210ec32f375a |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref> [[File:Webb-Ellis-at-Rugby,.jpg|thumb|160px|[[William Webb Ellis]] at [[Rugby School]], 1823-4]] * 1823 or 1824: Invention of [[Rugby football]] credited to [[William Webb Ellis]] (1806–1872). * 1848: [[Association football]]'s [[Cambridge rules]] (largely the sport's rules as we know them today) established at [[Cambridge University]].<ref name="Richard Cox page 5">Encyclopedia of British Football by Richard Cox et al., Routledge, 2002 page 5</ref> * 1850: The format of the modern [[Olympic Games]] inspired by [[William Penny Brookes]] (1809–1895); see also the [[Cotswold Olimpick Games]]. * c. 1850: A [[bowling machine]] for cricket named the Catapulta (a predecessor of the [[pitching machine]]) invented by [[Nicholas Felix|Nicholas "Felix" Wanostrocht]] (1804–1876).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/england/content/player/13019.html|title=Nicholas Felix|website=Cricinfo|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref> * 1857: [[Sheffield F.C.]] formed by former public school pupils, making it the world's first and oldest [[Association football]] club, as acknowledged by [[The Football Association]] and [[FIFA]].<ref name="Richard Cox page 5"/> * 1867: [[Coconut shy]] in [[Kingston, Surrey]]. * 1859–1865: [[Lawn tennis]] invented by [[Harry Gem]] (1819–1881) and [[Augurio Perera]], a Spanish-born merchant and sportsman based in England. * 1874–1875: [[Snooker]] invented by the [[British Army]] in India.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.snookerclub.com/snooker.shtml|title=Snooker|first=Phill|last=Hayes|website=Snookerclub.com|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref> * 1874: Formal codification of the rules of modern [[Polo]] established by the [[Hurlingham Polo Association]]; polo had been introduced to England in 1834 by the 10th [[Hussars]] at [[Aldershot]], Hants, and in 1862 the first polo club, [[Calcutta Polo Club]], was established by two British soldiers, Captain Robert Stewart and (later Major General) Joe Sherer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.calcuttapolo.com/corner.html|title=150 years Celebration-Unlocking a Power Brand|publisher=Calcutta Polo Club|accessdate=29 December 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110110233712/http://www.calcuttapolo.com/corner.html|archivedate=10 January 2011|df=}}</ref> * 1880 onwards: Modern [[rock climbing]] developed by [[Walter Parry Haskett Smith]] (1859–1946), so-called "father of rock climbing". * 1880s: [[Table tennis]] or ''ping-pong'' originated in [[Victorian era|Victorian]] England as an indoor version of tennis; it was developed and played by the [[upper class]] as an after-dinner [[parlour game]].<ref name=H2>{{Harvnb |Hodges|1993| p=2}}</ref><ref name="Letts">{{cite web |url=http://tabletennis.about.com/od/beginnersguide/a/history_of_tt.htm |title=A Brief History of Table Tennis/Ping-Pong|first=Greg |last=Letts |work=About.com |publisher=The New York Times Company |accessdate=29 August 2010}}</ref> * 1888: [[Tiddlywinks]] patent application by London bank clerk<ref>{{cite book|title=Census Returns of England and Wales|date=1891|publisher=The National Archives of the UK, Public Record Office|location=Kew, Surrey, England|page=Class: RG12; Piece: 1102; Folio: 18; Page: 14|url=https://search.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/sse.dll?indiv=1&dbid=6598&h=25030273&ssrc=pt&tid=64702480&pid=30161237741&usePUB=true|accessdate=28 March 2018}}</ref> Joseph Assheton Fincher (1863–1900)<ref>Joseph Assheton Fincher birth registration, General Register Office, England.</ref><ref>Joseph Assheton Fincher death registration, General Register Office, England.</ref>; tiddlywinks originated as an adult parlour game in [[Victorian era|Victorian]] England.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.etwa.org/|title=The English Tiddlywinks Association|website=Etwa.org|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref> * 1893–1897: [[Netball]] developed from early versions of [[women's basketball]] at [[Martina Bergman-Österberg|Madame Österberg]]'s College in England.<ref>{{cite web|author=International Federation of Netball Associations |title=History of Netball |url=http://www.netball.org/Netball.aspx?id=18 |accessdate=2008-10-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110306141537/http://www.netball.org/Netball.aspx?id=18 |archivedate=2011-03-06 |df= }}</ref> * 1895: [[Rugby league]] created with the establishment of the [[Rugby Football League|Northern Rugby Football Union]] (NRFU) as a breakaway faction of England's [[Rugby Football Union]] (RFU). * 1896: The dartboard-layout used in the game and professional competitive sport of [[Darts]] was devised by [[Lancashire]] carpenter Brian Gamlin (c. 1852–1903); Gamlin died before he could patent his idea.<ref>{{cite web |author=Darts Info World |title=History of Darts | url=http://dartsinfoworld.com/history-of-darts/ |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref> * 1899: [[Mixed martial arts|Mixed martial art]] (MMA) [[Bartitsu]] invented by [[Edward William Barton-Wright]] (1860–1951). * 1948: The first [[Paralympic games]] competition, originally the [[Stoke Mandeville Games]], created in England by German-born (from 1945 [[Naturalization|naturalised]]) British neurologist [[Ludwig Guttmann]] (1899–1980).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/paralympic-games/|title=Canada at the Paralympic Games|first=Patricia G.|last=Bailey|website=Thecanadianencyclopedia.ca|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref> * 1954: Sir [[Roger Bannister]] (1929–2018) ran the first sub-[[four-minute mile]] on 6 May 1954. * 1979: First modern [[Bungee jumping|bungee jump]]s made from the {{convert|250|ft|m|adj=on}} [[Clifton Suspension Bridge]] in [[Bristol]] by members of the [[Oxford University]] [[Dangerous Sports Club]].<ref>Aerial Extreme Sports (2008). [http://library.thinkquest.org/C0123122/historybungee.htm ''History of Bungee''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728105941/http://library.thinkquest.org/C0123122/historybungee.htm |date=July 28, 2011 }}. Retrieved on 17 October 2008.</ref>
==Transport== ===Aviation=== [[File:1843 engraving of the Aerial Steam Carriage.jpg|thumb|180px|The [[Aerial Steam Carriage]], performed the world's first powered flight in 1848]] * 1799: Concept of the modern aeroplane as a [[Fixed-wing aircraft|fixed-wing]] flying machine with separate systems for lift, propulsion, and control set forth by Sir [[George Cayley]] (1773–1857);<ref>{{cite web | title = Aviation History | url = http://www.aviation-history.com/early/cayley.htm | publisher = |accessdate=26 July 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Sir George Cayley (British Inventor and Scientist) | url = http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/100795/Sir-George-Cayley-6th-Baronet | publisher = Britannica | accessdate =26 July 2009 }}</ref> Cayley is one of the most important people in the history of [[Aeronautics]] and flight: he is sometimes called the "father of [[aviation]]".<ref name="wired_cayley">{{cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/science/discoveries/news/2003/12/61611|title=The Englishman Who Wanted to Fly|date=2003-12-16|author=Noah Shachtman|work=Wired Magazine|accessdate=2010-12-06}}</ref> * 1804: First [[glider aircraft|glider]] to carry a human being aloft designed by Sir [[George Cayley]] (1773–1857). Cayley discovered and identified the four aerodynamic forces of flight: [[weight]], [[Lift (force)|lift]], [[Drag (physics)|drag]], and [[thrust]]; Modern aeroplane design is based on those discoveries, along with [[Camber (aerodynamics)|cambered wings]] which Cayley also discovered.<ref name="wired_cayley"/> * 1837: Pioneering contribution to [[parachute]] design made by [[Robert Cocking]] (1776–1837); aged 61, Cocking was the first person to be killed in a parachuting accident. * 1844: Hale [[rocket]]s, an improved version of the [[Congreve rocket]] design that introduced [[thrust vectoring]], invented by [[William Hale (British inventor)|William Hale]] (1797–1870). * 1848: World's first powered flight (of 30 feet) achieved in [[Chard, Somerset]] with the [[Aerial Steam Carriage]] by [[John Stringfellow]] (1799–1883),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flyingmachines.org/strng.html|title=FLYING MACHINES – John Stringfellow|website=Flyingmachines.org|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref> 55 years before the [[Wright brothers]];<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zrpb67qFXUIC&pg=PT63&dq=1857+Temple+flight&lr=&sig=ACfU3U0s2bWJVVIn6IEYDXat5SKBPh93UA|title=First to Fly: North Carolina and the Beginnings of Aviation|first=Thomas C.|last=Parramore|date=1 March 2003|publisher=UNC Press Books|accessdate=6 January 2018|via=Google Books}}</ref> Stringfellow and [[William Samuel Henson]] (1812–1888) patented their invention in 1842.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/1591057.stm|title=High hopes for replica plane|date=10 October 2001|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=2010-12-06}}</ref> * Late-19th century: The term "[[airport|air port]]" first used – to describe the port city [[Southampton]], where some early [[flying boat]]s landed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discoversouthampton.co.uk/visit/history |title=Southampton History |publisher=Southampton City Council |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref> [[File:Comet BOAC 1960.jpg|thumb|The [[de Havilland Comet]], the first commercial [[jet airliner]], produced in 1949]] * 1929: [[Turbojet|Turbojet engine]] single-handedly invented by [[Sir Frank Whittle]] (1907–1996).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/whittle_frank.shtml|title=Frank Whittle (1907 – 1996)|publisher=BBC|accessdate=2010-12-06}}</ref> * 1949: First commercial [[jet airliner]], the [[de Havilland Comet]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/may/2/newsid_2480000/2480339.stm|title=1952: Comet inaugurates the jet age|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=2010-12-06|date=1952-05-02}}</ref> designed, developed and manufactured by [[de Havilland]]. * 1954: First aircraft capable of [[supercruise]], the [[English Electric Lightning]], designed, developed and manufactured by [[English Electric]]. * 1959: Aerospace engineer [[John Hodge (engineer)|John Hodge]] (born 1929) migrated to become part of [[NASA]]'s [[Space Task Group]], which was responsible for America's manned space programme, [[Project Mercury]]. * 1960: [[VTOL]] (Vertical Take-Off and Landing) aircraft (most famously the [[Harrier Jump Jet|Harrier]]) invented by [[Gordon Lewis (engineer)|Gordon Lewis]] (1924–2010), [[Ralph Hooper]] (born 1926), [[Stanley Hooker]] (1907–1984) and [[Sydney Camm]] (1893–1966);<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/6841130/Campaign-to-honour-Hawker-Hurricane-designer-Sir-Sydney-Camm.html|title=Campaign to honour Hawker Hurricane designer Sir Sydney Camm|date=26 Dec 2009|author=Gordon Rayner|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=2010-12-06|location=London}}</ref> the project developed on ideas by Frenchman Michel [[Wibault]].
===Railways=== * 1825: Opening of the [[Stockton and Darlington Railway]], the world's first operational [[steam locomotive|steam]] passenger railway; it was taken over by the [[North Eastern Railway (United Kingdom)|North Eastern Railway]] in 1863. * 1830: Opening of the [[Liverpool and Manchester Railway]], the first inter-city steam-powered railway; the railway was absorbed by the [[Grand Junction Railway]] in 1845. * 1838: Opening of the first stretch of the [[Great Western Railway]], from [[London Paddington station]] to (the original) [[Taplow railway station|Maidenhead]] station, engineered by [[Isambard Kingdom Brunel]] (1806–1859).
====Locomotives==== [[File:Coupler UK Rocket.JPG|thumb|180px|[[Stephenson's Rocket|Stephenson's ''Rocket'']], 1829]] * 1804: First full-scale railway [[steam locomotive]] built by [[Richard Trevithick]] (1771–1833).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/southeastwales/hi/people_and_places/history/newsid_8024000/8024766.stm|title=Trevithick the railway pioneer|date=29 April 2009|publisher=BBC|accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref>. This built on the endeavours of two other Englishmen, engineer Thomas Savery (c.1650–1715) , son of Devon, and the first practical steam engine built in 1712 by Londoner [[Thomas Newcomen]] (c.1664–1729). [[James Watt]] did not invent the steam engine. Rather Watt, prompted by English backer and manufacturer Matthew Boulton, effected improvements sufficient to make the invention commercial viable. * 1812: First commercially viable steam locomotive, the twin cylinder ''[[Salamanca (locomotive)|Salamanca]]'', designed and built by [[Matthew Murray]] (1765–1826) of [[Holbeck]]. * 1813: First practical steam locomotive to rely simply on the adhesion of iron wheels on iron rails, ''[[Puffing Billy (locomotive)|Puffing Billy]]'', built by [[William Hedley]] (1779–1843). * 1814: First successful [[Flange|flanged-wheel]] adhesion locomotive, the ''[[Blücher (locomotive)|Blücher]]'', built by [[George Stephenson]] (1781–1848). * 1824: First steam locomotive to carry passengers on a public rail-line, the ''[[Locomotion No. 1]]'', built by [[Robert Stephenson]] (1803–1859), son of [[George Stephenson]]. * 1829: [[Stephenson's Rocket|Stephenson's ''Rocket'']] built by [[George Stephenson]] (1781–1848) and his son [[Robert Stephenson]] (1803–1859); the ''Rocket'' was not the first steam locomotive, but it was the first to bring together several innovations to produce the most advanced locomotive of its day. * 1829: The ''[[Sans Pareil]]'', a less advanced competitor of [[Stephenson's Rocket|Stephenson's ''Rocket'']], built by [[Timothy Hackworth]] (1786–1850). * 1829: The ''[[Stourbridge Lion]]'', first steam locomotive to be operated in the [[United States]], built by [[Foster, Rastrick and Company]] of [[Stourbridge]], [[Worcestershire]], now West Midlands; the manufacturing company was headed by [[James Foster (ironmaster)|James Foster]] (1786–1853) and [[John Urpeth Rastrick]] (1780–1856). * 1923: The ''[[LNER Class A3 4472 Flying Scotsman|Flying Scotsman]]'' built to a design by [[Sir Nigel Gresley]] (1876–1941);<ref>[http://www.gresley.org.uk/biog_has.htm biography] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130727094831/http://www.gresley.org.uk/biog_has.htm |date=2013-07-27 }} accessed 15 November 2014</ref> the ''Flying Scotsman'' was in 1934 the first steam locomotive to be authenticated at reaching {{convert|100|mph|sigfig=4}} in passenger service.<ref name=heritagetrail>{{cite web|title=British Railway Heritage – 4472 The Flying Scotsman |url=http://www.theheritagetrail.co.uk/industrial/flying%20scotsman.htm |publisher=theheritagetrail.co.uk |accessdate=6 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150621104329/http://www.theheritagetrail.co.uk/industrial/flying%20scotsman.htm |archivedate=21 June 2015 |df= }}</ref>
====Other railway developments==== [[File:GWR broad gauge Metropolitan Class.jpg|thumb|160px|The [[London Underground]], opened 1863]] * 1842: The [[Edmondson railway ticket]] invented by [[Thomas Edmondson]] (1792–1851); British Rail used Edmondson tickets until February 1990.<ref>{{cite book|last=Farr|first=Michael|title=Thomas Edmondson and his Tickets|location=Andover|publisher=Author|year=1991|isbn=978-0-905033-13-6|ref=harv}}</ref> * 1852 onwards: Numerous inventions for railways by [[John Ramsbottom (engineer)|John Ramsbottom]] (1814–1897), including: the split [[piston ring]] (1852), the Ramsbottom [[safety valve]] (1855), the [[Displacement lubricator]] (1860), and the [[Track pan|water trough]] (1860). * 1863: Opening of the world's oldest underground railway, the [[London Underground]], a.k.a. the Tube; the Tube is the oldest [[rapid transit]] system, and it was the first underground railway to operate [[electric locomotive|electric trains]]. * Late 1940s: [[Maglev]], the use of magnetic levitation to move vehicles without touching the ground, invented by [[Eric Laithwaite]] (1921–1997). * 1981: The [[Advanced Passenger Train]] (APT), an experimental [[High-speed rail|high-speed train]] that pioneered [[tilting train|tilting]], introduced by [[British Rail]]. 1835 – Der Adler. First steam locomotive in Germany. Built by George & Robert Stephenson in Newcastle.
===Roads=== [[File:HansomCab.gif|thumb|180px|The [[Hansom cab]], invented by [[Joseph Hansom]] in 1834]] * 1804: The [[seat belt]] invented by Sir [[George Cayley]] (1773–1857).<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/features/Clunk-click--an-invention.5583475.jp?articlepage=1|title=Clunk, click – an invention that's saved lives for 50 years|author=Manby, Frederic|date=24 August 2009|accessdate=2010-12-04|publisher=Johnston Press Digital Publishing|newspaper=Yorkshire Post}}</ref> * 1808: Tension-spoke [[wire wheels]] invented by Sir [[George Cayley]] (1773–1857).<ref name="wired_cayley"/> * 1829: First practical steam [[fire engine]] invented by [[John Braithwaite (engineer)|John Braithwaite]] the younger (1797–1880). * 1834: The [[Hansom cab]], a type of horse-drawn carriage, invented by [[Joseph Hansom]] (1803–1882). * 1868: First [[traffic light]]s (manually operated and [[Gas lighting|gas-lit]]) installed outside London's [[Houses of Parliament]]; invented by [[J. P. Knight|John Peake Knight]] (1828–1886). * c. 1870: "Ariel", a [[penny-farthing]] bicycle, developed by [[James Starley]] (1831–1881). * 1876: The legal collection of 70,000 thousands seeds from the rubber bearing tree [[hevea brasiliensis]] which led to the discovery of the perfect growing climate and locations for rubber trees by [[Sir Henry Alexander Wickham]]. Most commercial rubber plants are descended from the seeds he took to [[Kew Gardens]] * 1884:Thomas Parker claimed to have invented the first [[electric car]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/howaboutthat/5212278/Worlds-first-electric-electric-car-built-by-Victorian-inventor-in-1884.html|title=World's first electric car built by Victorian inventor in 1884|date=24 April 2009|accessdate=6 January 2018|website=Telegraph.co.uk}}</ref> * 1885: First commercially successful [[safety bicycle]], "the Rover", developed by [[John Kemp Starley]] (1855–1901). * 1901: [[Tarmacadam|Tarmac]] patented by [[Edgar Purnell Hooley]] (1860–1942). * c. 1902: The invention of the [[Bowden cable]] popularly attributed to Sir [[Sir Frank Bowden, 1st Baronet|Frank Bowden]] (1848–1921), founder and owner of the [[Raleigh Bicycle Company]]. * 1910: Opening of the oldest existing driving school and first formal driving tuition provider, the [[British School of Motoring]], in [[Peckham]], London.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/motoring/road-safety/7937429/100-years-of-the-driving-lesson.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | title=100 Years Of The Driving Lesson | first=David | last=Williams | date=2010-08-19}}</ref> * 1922: [[Horstmann suspension]], a [[coil spring]] [[Suspension (vehicle)|suspension]] system commonly used on western [[tanks]]s, invented by [[Sidney Horstmann]] (1881–1962). * 1926: First automated traffic lights in England deployed in [[Piccadilly Circus]] in 1926;<ref>{{cite web|title=Traffic Controls|url=http://www.museumoflondon.org.uk/Collections-Research/Research/Your-Research/X20L/Themes/1/1240/|work=Exploring 20th Century London|publisher=The Museum of London|accessdate=24 June 2013}}</ref> outside of London, [[Wolverhampton]] was in 1927 the first British town to introduce automated traffic lights.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wolverhampton.gov.uk/transport_streets/motor/management/control.htm |title=Traffic Control and Traffic Signals |publisher=Wolverhampton City Council |accessdate=1 July 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080920084143/http://www.wolverhampton.gov.uk/transport_streets/motor/management/control.htm |archivedate=20 September 2008 |df= }}</ref> * 1934: The [[Cat's eye (road)|Cat's eye]], a [[Road safety|safety device]] used in [[road marking]], invented by [[Percy Shaw]] (1890–1976).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.halifaxtoday.co.uk/mk4custompages/CustomPage.aspx?PageID=39556 |title=The day Percy saw the light! |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040312081747/http://www.halifaxtoday.co.uk/mk4custompages/CustomPage.aspx?PageID=39556 |archivedate=2004-03-12 |df= }}</ref> * 1934: The [[Belisha beacon]] introduced by [[Leslie Hore-Belisha]] (1893–1957). * 1962: First modern [[Formula One]] car, the [[Lotus 25]], designed by [[Colin Chapman]] (1928–1982) for [[Team Lotus]]; the design incorporated the first fully stressed [[monocoque]] [[chassis]] to appear in automobile racing. * 1985: The [[Sinclair C5]], a one-person [[battery electric vehicle]], invented by Sir [[Clive Sinclair]] (born 1940). * 1997: World [[Land Speed Record]], 1,228 km/h (763 mph), achieved by [[ThrustSSC]], a [[jet engine|jet]]-propelled car designed and built in England. Project director: [[Richard Noble]] (born 1946); designed by [[Ron Ayers]] (born 1932), Glynne Bowsher and Jeremy Bliss; piloted by [[Andy Green]] (born 1962).
===Sea=== [[File:SRN4 Hovercraft in Dover 1.jpg|thumb|180px|[[Hovercraft]], invented by Sir [[Christopher Cockerell]] in 1955]] * 1578: The first [[submersible]] (a small, [[submarine]]-like vehicle) of whose construction there exists reliable information designed by Englishman [[William Bourne (mathematician)|William Bourne]] (c. 1535–1582) in his book ''Inventions or Devises''; Dutchman [[Cornelius Drebbel]] put Bourne's concept into action in 1620. * 1691: A [[diving bell]] capable of allowing its occupier to remain submerged for extended periods of time, and fitted with a window for the purpose of underwater exploration, designed by [[Edmond Halley|Edmund Halley]] (1656–1742),<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Edmonds |first1=Carl |last2=Lowry |first2=C |last3=Pennefather |first3=John |title=History of diving |journal=[[South Pacific Underwater Medicine Society]] Journal |volume=5 |issue=2 |year=1975 |url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/5894 |accessdate=2012-11-26}}</ref> best known for computing the orbit of [[Halley's Comet]]. * c. 1730: The [[Octant (instrument)|octant]] invented by English mathematician [[John Hadley]] (1682–1744); American optician [[Thomas Godfrey (inventor)|Thomas Godfrey]] developed the instrument independently at approximately the same time. * 1743: The "Whirling Speculum", a device used to locate the [[horizon]] in foggy or misty conditions, invented by [[John Serson]] (died 1744); Serson's Speculum can be seen as a precursor to the [[gyroscope]]. * 1757: First [[Reflecting instrument|sextant]] made by [[John Bird (astronomer)|John Bird]] (1709–1776),<ref>Turner, Gerard, ''Antique Scientific Instruments'', Blandford Press Ltd. 1980 {{ISBN|0-7137-1068-3}}</ref> adapting the principle of [[John Hadley|Hadley]]'s [[Octant (instrument)|octant]]. * 1785: The [[Lifeboat (rescue)|lifeboat]] invented and patented by [[Lionel Lukin]] (1742–1834); [[William Wouldhave]] (1751–1821) made a rival claim, but he did not succeed with the practical application of his invention until 1789. * 1799: The [[Transit (ship)|Transit]], a type of sailing vessel with a remarkable turn of speed, patented by [[Richard Hall Gower]] (1768–1833). * 1835: The [[screw propeller]] invented and patented by [[Francis Pettit Smith]] (1808–1874). * 1843: Launch of the [[SS Great Britain]] – the first steam-powered, screw propeller-driven passenger liner with an iron hull; designed by [[Isambard Kingdom Brunel]] (1806–1859), it was at the time the largest ship afloat. * 1876: [[Plimsoll Line]] devised by [[Samuel Plimsoll]] (1824–1898). * 1878: First commercially successful closed-circuit [[Scuba diving|scuba]] designed and built by [[Henry Fleuss]] (1851–1932), a pioneer in the field of [[diving equipment]]. * 1878–1879: Two early [[Victorian era|Victorian]] [[submarine]]s, [[Resurgam]] I and Resurgam II, designed and built by [[George Garrett (inventor)|George Garrett]] (1852–1902). * 1894: The first [[steam turbine]] powered [[steamship]], [[Turbinia]] (easily the fastest ship in the world at the time), designed by [[Anglo-Irish]] engineer Sir [[Charles Algernon Parsons]] (1854–1931), and built in [[Newcastle upon Tyne]]. * 1899–1901: Developments on the [[hydrofoil]] by shipbuilder [[John Isaac Thornycroft]] (1843–1928), from the concept of Italian [[Enrico Forlanini]]. * 1912: World's first patent for an underwater echo ranging device ([[sonar]]) filed a month after the sinking of the ''[[RMS Titanic|Titanic]]'' by [[Lewis Richardson]] (1881–1953). * 1915: Research into solving the practical problems of [[submarine]]-detection by [[sonar]] led by [[Ernest Rutherford]] (1871–1937).<ref>{{cite web|title=Traffic Controls|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/manchester-scientist-ernest-rutherford-revealed-8078891 |work=Manchester scientist Ernest Rutherford revealed as top secret mastermind behind sonar technology | publisher=Manchester Evening News |accessdate=8 November 2016}}</ref> * 1955: The [[hovercraft]] invented by Sir [[Christopher Cockerell]] (1910–1999).
==Miscellaneous== [[File:Robert-baden-powell-on-my-honor.jpg|thumb|160px|[[Robert Baden-Powell, 1st Baron Baden-Powell|Lord Baden-Powell]], invented the [[Scouting|scout movement]] in 1907]] * 1286: First recorded use of the [[Halifax Gibbet]], an early [[guillotine]]. * Early 17th century: The closely cut [[Lawn|"English" lawn]] created in the [[Jacobean era|Jacobean]] epoch of [[History of gardening|gardening]], as the garden and the lawn became places created first as walkways and social areas. The English lawn became a symbol of status of the [[aristocracy]] and [[gentry]]; it showed that the owner could afford to keep land that was not being used for a building or for food production. * 1668: Earliest concept of a [[metric system]] proposed by [[John Wilkins]] (1614–1672) in ''[[An Essay towards a Real Character and a Philosophical Language]]''. * 1706: World's first life insurance company, the [[Amicable Society for a Perpetual Assurance Office|Amicable Society]], founded by [[William Talbot (bishop)|William Talbot]] (1658–1730) and Sir [[Allen baronets|Thomas Allen, 2nd Baronet]] (c. 1648–1730). * 1719: Oldest music-based [[arts festival|festival]], the [[Three Choirs Festival]], established. * 1725: The modern [[History of the kilt|kilt]], associated since the 19th century with [[Scottish culture]], arguably invented by English [[Quakers|Quaker]] [[Thomas Rawlinson]] (dates not known).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://skilt.co.uk/tag/who-designed-the-kilt/|title=Who designed the kilt? – Modern kilts for men for sale|website=skilt.co.uk|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1982040/Kilts-invented-by-English-in-Lord-Dacres-book.html |title=Kilts invented by English in Lord Dacre's book |publisher=The Telegraph |accessdate=14 January 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/kilt-was-invented-by-an-englishman-claims-jeremy-paxman-to-scots-anger-9466796.html |title=Kilt was invented by an Englishman, claims Jeremy Paxman, to Scots anger |publisher=Independent |accessdate=14 January 2016 }}</ref> * c. 1760: The [[jigsaw puzzle]] invented and commercialised by [[cartographer]] [[John Spilsbury (cartographer)|John Spilsbury]] (1739–1769).<ref>{{cite web|last1=McAdam|first1=Daniel|title=History of Jigsaw Puzzles|url=http://www.jigsaw-puzzle.org/jigsaw-puzzle-history.html|publisher=American Jigsaw Puzzle Society |accessdate=13 October 2014}}</ref> * 1767: The [[Carbonation|carbonated]] [[soft drink]] invented by [[Joseph Priestley]] (1733–1804). * 1768–1770: The modern [[circus]] invented by [[Philip Astley]] (1742–1814) in [[Astley's Amphitheatre]] on [[Westminster Bridge]] Road in [[Lambeth]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/2929565.stm |title=The circus comes to the Circus |publisher=BBC |accessdate=14 January 2016 }}</ref><ref>Schechter, Joel (2001) [https://books.google.com/books?id=srrIxji0PvQC&pg=PA11&dq=british%20sergeant%20major%20philip%20astley&hl=en&ei=n6RATauLDcGphAekw423CA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=british%20sergeant%20major%20philip%20astley&f=false The pickle clowns: new American circus comedy] p.11. Southern Illinois University Press</ref> * c. 1770: The [[lorgnette]] (a pair of [[Glasses|spectacles]] with a handle, used to hold them in place, rather than fitting over the ears or nose) invented by [[George Adams (instrument maker, elder)|George Adams I]] (c. 1709–1773) and subsequently illustrated in his son [[George Adams (1750–1795)|George Adams II]]'s ''An Essay on Vision, briefly explaining the fabric of the eye'' (1789).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.college-optometrists.org/en/college/museyeum/online_exhibitions/spectacles/lorgnettes.cfm |title=Lorgnettes and folding eyeglasses |publisher=The College of Optometrists, London |accessdate=14 January 2016 }}</ref> * 1772: Oldest [[arts festival]] established in [[Norwich]] 1772.<ref>[http://www.norwich.gov.uk/internet_docs/docs/Unitary_Council/AnnexB.pdf Key Facts about Norwich<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070621211721/http://www.norwich.gov.uk/internet_docs/docs/Unitary_Council/AnnexB.pdf |date=June 21, 2007 }}</ref> * 1787: First [[glee club]] founded in [[Harrow School]].<ref name="firstgleeclub">{{cite journal |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bbYPAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA324&dq=history+of+%22glee+clubs%22 |last=Bacon |first=Richard Mackenzie |authorlink=Richard Mackenzie Bacon |title=The Catch and Glee Clubs |journal=The Quarterly musical magazine and review |volume=II |issue=VII |pages=328ff |location=London |year=1820 }}</ref> * 1797: The [[top hat]] arguably invented by English [[haberdasher]] [[John Hetherington]] (dates not known). [[File:An Essay on the Principle of Population.jpg|thumb|160px|[[Thomas Robert Malthus|Malthus]]'s ''[[An Essay on the Principle of Population|Essay on the Principle of Population]]'', 1798]] * 1798: Consequences of [[population growth]] identified by [[Thomas Robert Malthus]] (1766–1834) in ''[[An Essay on the Principle of Population]]''. * 1798: Oldest police force in continuous operation, the [[Marine Police Force]], formed by English seafarer [[John Harriott]] (1745–1817) and Scot [[Patrick Colquhoun]]; it merged with the nascent[[Metropolitan Police Service]] in 1839. * 18th century – 19th century: The [[history of comics]] developed with innovations by [[William Hogarth]] (1697–1764), [[James Gillray]] (1756/57–1815), [[George Cruikshank]] (1792–1878) and others. The Glasgow Looking Glass (1826), arguably the first comic strip. William Heath was its principal strip illustrator.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sil.si.edu/ondisplay/caricatures/bio_hogarth.htm|title=William Hogarth Caricature Biography|website=Sil.si.edu|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://theconversation.com/inside-the-pages-of-the-oldest-comic-in-the-world-56225|title=Inside the pages of the oldest comic in the world|first=Laurence|last=Grove|website=Theconversation.com|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref> * 1811: The [[graphic telescope]], a [[camera lucida|drawing aid]] with the power of a [[telescope]], invented by [[water-colour]] painter [[Cornelius Varley]] (1781–1873). * 1821: World's first modern [[nature reserve]] established by [[naturalist]] and [[explorer]] [[Charles Waterton]] (1782–1965); Waterton was described by [[David Attenborough]] as "one of the first people anywhere to recognise not only that the natural world was of great importance but that it needed protection as humanity made more and more demands on it".<ref>{{cite web|author=Wakefield Express |url=http://www.wakefieldexpress.co.uk/news/local/more-wakefield-news/sir-david-attenborough-will-open-city-centre-s-new-museum-1-5439242 |title=Sir David Attenborough will open city centre's new museum |publisher= |date=2013-02-23 |accessdate=2014-08-24}}</ref> * 1824: Rubber [[balloon]] invented by [[Michael Faraday]] (1791–1867) during experiments with gases. * 1824: First [[animal welfare]] society, the [[Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals|RSPCA]], founded by a group of reformers including [[William Wilberforce]]. * 1826: First effective friction [[match]] invented by [[John Walker (inventor)|John Walker]] (1781–1859). * 1829: [[Metropolitan Police Force]] founded by [[Home Secretary]] Sir [[Robert Peel]]; by 1857 all cities in the UK were obliged to form their own police forces. * 1840: [[Stamp collecting]] initiated by zoologist [[John Edward Gray]] (1800–1875); on 1 May 1840, the day the [[Penny Black]] first went on sale, Gray bought several with the intent to save them.<ref>Gray, John Edward, ''A Hand Catalogue of Postage Stamps for the use of the Collector'', 1862, Robert Hardwicke, page viii [https://books.google.com/books?id=a5YDAAAAQAAJ&ots=fXq6jrKBT0&dq=A%20hand%20catalogue%20of%20postage%20stamps&pg=PR3#v=onepage&q&f=false Free download here.]</ref> * 1844: The [[Rochdale Society of Equitable Pioneers]] founded in [[Lancashire]]. The [[Rochdale Principles]] are the foundation for the [https://ica.coop/en/whats-co-op/co-operative-identity-values-principles co-operative principles] on which co-ops around the world operate to this day. * 1844: The [[YMCA]] (Young Men's Christian Association) founded in London by Sir [[George Williams (YMCA)|George Williams]] (1821–1905), with the aim of putting [[Christian values]] into practice. * 1846: The [[Christmas cracker]] invented by London confectioner [[Thomas J. Smith]] by wrapping a bon-bon in a twist of coloured paper, adding a love note, a paper hat and a banger mechanism. This new idea took of and the bon-bon was eventually replaced by a small toy or novelty. * 1849: [[Bowler hat]] designed by London hat-makers Thomas and William Bowler. * 1851: [[Prime meridian]] established at [[Greenwich]] by Sir [[George Biddell Airy]] (1801–1892), [[Astronomer Royal]] from 1835 to 1881); Airy's line, the fourth [[Prime meridian (Greenwich)|Greenwich Meridian]], became the definitive, internationally recognised line in 1884. [[File:Nullmeridian.jpg|thumb|160px|[[Prime meridian]], established at [[Greenwich]], 1851]] * 1851: Revolutionary [[Modular design|modular]], [[Prefabrication|prefabricated]] design, and use of [[Architectural glass|glass]] utilised in the building of [[the Crystal Palace]] of the [[Great Exhibition]] by [[Joseph Paxton]] (1803–1865); after the exhibition, the Crystal Palace was moved to [[Sydenham]] where it was destroyed in a fire in 1936. * 1851: Steel-ribbed [[umbrella]] developed by [[Samuel Fox (industrialist)|Samuel Fox]] (1815–1887). * 1860: [[Linoleum]] invented by [[Frederick Walton]] (1834–1928).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/index/101067799/|title=Frederick Walton : Oxford Biography Index entry|website=Oxforddnb.com|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref> * 1865: [[The Salvation Army]], a [[Christian denomination|Christian denominational church]] and international [[charitable organization|charitable organisation]], founded by [[Methodist]] [[minister (Christianity)|minister]] [[William Booth]] (1829–1912). * 1866: The introduction, planting, cultivation and manufacturing of [[Ceylon tea]] in the British Crown colony of Ceylon, now [[Sri Lanka]]. [[Sir Arthur Conan Doyle]] said of the planting efforts "the tea fields of Ceylon were as true a monument to courage as the lions of Waterloo" and called it "one of the greatest commercial victories which pluck and ingenuity ever won."<ref>pureceylontea.com/index.php/tea-saves-the-day</ref> * 1868: Erection of first mounted dinosaur skeleton, Hadrosaurus Foulkii and introduction of the universal standard for all future dinosaur displays by English artist [[Benjamin Waterhouse Hawkins]] in concert with Dr Joseph Leidy and Edward Drinker Cope. Displayed at [[The Academy of Natural Sciences]] * 1870s: One precursor (among others) of the modern [[gas mask]] constructed by physicist [[John Tyndall]] (1820–1893). * 1897: [[Plasticine]] invented by art teacher [[William Harbutt]] (1844–1921). * 1901: [[Scale model|Model]] [[construction]] system [[Meccano]] invented by [[Frank Hornby]] (1863–1936). * 1902: First large-scale programme of international [[scholarship]]s, the [[Rhodes Scholarship]], created by [[Cecil John Rhodes]] (1853–1902). * 1907: The [[Scouting|scout movement]] created by [[Robert Baden-Powell, 1st Baron Baden-Powell|Lord Baden-Powell]] (1857–1941), on finding that his 1899 [[Military education and training|military training]] manual ''Aids to Scouting'' was being used by teachers and youth organisations.<ref name="best-seller">{{cite web |last=Peterson |first=Robert |title=Marching to a Different Drummer |work=Scouting |publisher=Boy Scouts of America |year=2003 |url=http://www.scoutingmagazine.org/issues/0310/d-wwas.html |accessdate=2 January 2007}}</ref> *1908: The reserve forest which would become the [[Kaziranga National Park]] founded by [[George Curzon, 1st Marquess Curzon of Kedleston|Lord Curzon of Kedleston]] to protect the dwindling species of [[rhinoceros]]. * 1913: The [[crossword puzzle]] invented by [[Liverpool]]-born [[Arthur Wynne]] (1871–1945). * 1922: Discovery of [[Tutankhamun]]'s tomb by Archaeologist and Egyptologist [[Howard Carter]], funded by Lord Carnarvon. * 1933: [[Bayko]] – a [[plastic]] [[building model]] construction [[toy]], and one of the earliest plastic toys to be marketed<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.melright.com/bayko/ |title=The Bayko system |work=Bayko Building Site |first=Melvyn |last=Wright |accessdate=2007-03-14}}</ref> – invented by [[Charles Plimpton]] (1893–1948). * 1946: [[Construction set|Toy building bricks]] invented and patented (under the name "[[Kiddicraft]]") by Hilary (Harry) Fisher Page (1904–1957); [[Lego]] acquired Page's patent in 1981.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hilarypagetoys.com/history.php?his_id=4 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-01-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130508131834/http://www.hilarypagetoys.com/history.php?his_id=4 |archivedate=2013-05-08 |df= }}</ref> * 1949: Oldest [[literary festival]], the [[Cheltenham Literature Festival]], established. * 1965: [[Geometric]] drawing toy [[Spirograph]] developed by [[Denys Fisher]] (1918–2002).

'''Micro process engineering''' is the science of conducting chemical or physical processes ([[unit operation]]s) inside small volumina, typically inside channels with diameters of less than 1 mm (microchannels) or other structures with sub-millimeter dimensions. These processes are usually carried out in continuous flow mode, as opposed to [[batch production]], allowing a throughput high enough to make micro process engineering a tool for chemical production. Micro process engineering is therefore not to be confused with microchemistry, which deals with very small overall quantities of matter.
The subfield of micro process engineering that deals with chemical reactions, carried out in microstructured reactors or "[[microreactor]]s", is also known as '''microreaction technology'''.
The unique advantages of microstructured reactors or ''[[microreactor]]s'' are [[enhanced heat transfer]] due to the large surface [[area-to-volume ratio]], and enhanced [[mass transfer]]. For example, the length scale of [[diffusion]] processes is comparable to that of microchannels or even shorter, and efficient mixing of [[reactant]]s can be achieved during very short times (typically milliseconds). The good heat transfer properties allow a precise temperature control of reactions. For example, highly [[exothermic reaction]]s can be conducted almost [[isothermal]]ly when the microstructured reactor contains a second set of microchannels ("cooling passage"), fluidically separated from the reaction channels ("reaction passage"), through which a flow of cold fluid with sufficiently high [[heat capacity]] is maintained. It is also possible to change the temperature of microstructured reactors very rapidly to intentionally achieve a non-isothermal behaviour.
==Process intensification==
While the dimensions of the individual channels are small, a micro process engineering device ("microstructured reactor") can contain many thousands of such channels, and the overall size of a microstructured reactor can be on the scale of meters. The objective of micro process engineering is not primarily to miniaturize production plants, but to increase [[Yield (chemistry)|yields]] and selectivities of chemical reactions, thus reducing the cost of chemical production. This goal can be achieved by either using chemical reactions that cannot be conducted in larger volumina, or by running chemical reactions at parameters (temperatures, pressures, concentrations) that are inaccessible in larger volumina due to safety constraints. For example, the detonation of the [[stoichiometric]] mixture of two volume unit of [[hydrogen]] gas and one volume unit of [[oxygen]] gas does not propagate in microchannels with a sufficiently small diameter. This property is referred to as the "[[intrinsic safety]]" of microstructured reactors. The improvement of yields and selectivities by using novel reactions or running reactions at more extreme parameters is known as "process intensification".
==History==
Historically, micro process engineering originated around the 1980s, when mechanical micromachining methods developed for the fabrication of [[uranium]] [[isotope separation]] nozzles were first applied to the manufacturing of compact [[heat exchanger]]s at the [[Forschungszentrum Karlsruhe|Karlsruhe (Nuclear) Research Center]].
==See also== * [[Microreactor]] * [[Flow chemistry]]

{{Expand Russian|topic=bio|Агурский, Михаил Самуилович|date=April 2014}} '''Mikhail Samuilovich Agursky''' ({{lang-ru|Михаи́л Самуи́лович Агу́рский}}; 1933 – 21 August 1991), real name '''Melik Samuilovich Agursky''' ({{lang-ru|Мэ́лик Самуилович Агу́рский}}), was a [[Jews|Jewish]] [[Kremlinology|sovietologist]], [[Cybernetics|cybernetic]][http://enc-dic.com/politic/Agurskij-Mihail-Melik-Samuilovich-14.html Политический словарь: Агурский Михаил] and [[historian]] of [[National Bolshevism]].[http://nbp-info.ru/new/lib/ag_nb/ Михаил Агурский. Идеология национал-большевизма] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100404053643/http://nbp-info.ru/new/lib/ag_nb/ |date=2010-04-04 }} Agursky was a member of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences|Soviet Academy of Sciences]] and [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]].
Mikhail Agursky was the [[pen name]] of Melik Agursky. Other variations of the name are ''Melir'' ({{lang-ru|Мэлир}}) and ''Melib'' ({{lang-ru|Мэлиб}}). He was the son of a famous revolutionary, a historian and party leader Samuel (Shmuel) Haimovich Agursky (1884-1947). In 1955 he married Vera Feodorovna Kondratieva. ==Biography== [[File:IzPodGlib.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Cover of ''из-под глыб '' (Under the Ruble) a [[Samizdat]] book to which Agursky contributed (1974)]] Mikhail Agursky was born as '''Melik Samuilovich Agursky''' (Мэ́лик Самуилович Агу́рский) in [[Moscow]] in 1933 to a Jewish family. His father Samuel Agursky was revolutionary and historian.[http://www.livelib.ru/author/171758 Михаил Агурский - Биография] Mikhail Agursky received an education in engineering and defended a dissertation on [[cybernetics]].[http://berkovich-zametki.com/Avtory/Agursky.htm Заметки по еврейской истории: Михаил Агурский] In 1975 he emigrated to [[Israel]].[http://berkovich-zametki.com/Avtory/Agursky.htm Заметки по еврейской истории: Михаил Агурский] Agursky became a Fellow of the Soviet and East European Research Center at the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]]. His book "The Ideology of [[National Bolshevism]]" was published in [[Paris]] in 1980.[http://www.jcrelations.net/Agursky__Mikhail.466.0.html Mikhail Agursky (1933-1991)] On 21 August 1991 Agursky was found dead on in his hotel room in Moscow.[https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/30/obituaries/dr-mikhail-agursky-ex-soviet-scientist-58-jerusalem-aug-29.html Dr. Mikhail Agursky, Ex-Soviet Scientist] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100404053643/http://nbp-info.ru/new/lib/ag_nb/ Mikhail Agursky - The Ideology of National Bolshevism] (in Russian) {{Soviet dissidents}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Agursky, Mikhail}} [[Category:1933 births]] [[Category:1991 deaths]] [[Category:National Bolsheviks]] [[Category:Russian Jews]] [[Category:Soviet dissidents]] [[Category:Soviet emigrants to Israel]] [[Category:Cyberneticists]] [[Category:Soviet literary historians]] [[Category:Soviet male writers]] [[Category:20th-century male writers]] [[Category:Soviet cyberneticists]]

{{Infobox Interbank Network | name = Multibanco | logo = [[File:Multibanco.svg]] | area = [[Portugal]] | foundation = 1985 | members = 27 | atm = 11,440}} '''Multibanco''' is an [[interbank network]] in [[Portugal]] owned and operated by [[Sociedade Interbancária de Serviços S.A.]], or SIBS, that links the [[automated teller machine|ATMs]] of 27 banks in Portugal, totaling 12,700 machines as of December 2014. The bank members of Multibanco control the SIBS. Multibanco is a fully integrated interbank network. One of the most notable characteristics of Multibanco is the wide range of services that can be utilised through its machines.{{cite web|url=http://www.sibs.pt/noticia.php?id=137 |title=Multibanco português é dos mais avançados do mundo |accessdate=2006-12-19 |publisher=Sociedade Interbancaria de Serviços S.A., citing Portuguese newspaper ''Semanário Económico'' in its 2006-10-27 edition. "A qualidade do sistema português de máquinas Automated Teller Machine (ATM) é reconhecida em qualquer ponto do globo, não só pela modernidade dos equipamentos como pela enorme quantidade de funcionalidades disponíveis." (The quality of the Portuguese system is recognized anywhere in the globe, not only for the modernity of its equipment, but also for the enormous amount of functionalities available.) |language=pt |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927043648/http://www.sibs.pt/noticia.php?id=137 |archivedate=September 27, 2007 }} Multibanco in itself does not only encompass ATMs. It has a fully-fledged [[Electronic funds transfer|EFTPOS]] network called [[Multibanco Automatic Payment]], and is also a provider of mobile phone and Internet banking services through the [[TeleMultibanco]] and [[MBNet]] services respectively. It is also the provider of the [[Via Verde]] automated toll payment service. ==History== [[File:Cax aut1.jpg|thumb|180px|Multibanco's old logo (1985–2008).]] The Caixa Automático Multibanco (Multibanco ATM) was the first project developed by SIBS and started operating on September 2, 1985, with the installation of 12 terminals in the cities of [[Lisbon]] and [[Porto]].{{cite web |url= http://www.sibs.pt/en/conteudo.php?id=43&type=0|title=Multibanco: ATM Network|accessdate= 2006-12-19|publisher = SIBS |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061003221314/http://www.sibs.pt/en/conteudo.php?id=43&type=0 |archivedate = 2006-10-03}} In 1995, the network had 3,745 ATMs; in 2006 had more than 11,200; and as of December 2014 it had 12,700, on which an average of more than 75 million operations are made every month.https://mbway.azurewebsites.net/sibsfps/wp-content/uploads/sites/5/2015/08/SIBS_Market_Report_JUL2015.pdf#page=9 ==Functionality== Multibanco is known for having more functionality than standard ATMs in other countries. Initially, the machines only offered withdrawal of cash, checking of balances and checking of recent transactions. Later, features such as service and shopping payments, [[Prepaid mobile phone]] top-up and show ticket sales, among others, were introduced. Nowadays, 60 different services are offered by the Multibanco network.{{cite web |url= http://www.sibs.pt/en/conteudo.php?id=135&type=0|title= ATM Network: Operations|accessdate= 2006-12-19|publisher = SIBS |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061003222419/http://www.sibs.pt/en/conteudo.php?id=135&type=0 |archivedate = 2006-10-03}} ==Usage== From 2001 to 2005, the average number of transactionsIncludes cash withdrawals, deposits, account and transfers checking, payments and "other operations" by year is over 630 million. The number has been rising every year; 719 million were recorded in 2005. This has since grown substantially, with 900 million operations recorded in 2014. {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:95%" ! Year ! Number
of ATMs ! Total number of
transactions |- |2001 |8,482 |527,417,947 |- |2002 |9,032 |588,806,749 |- |2003 |9,521 |631,912,059 |- |2004 |10,085 |683,764,445 |- |2005 |10,723 |719,006,591 |- |2014 |12,700 |900,000,000 |} ==Security== Multibanco allows users with a local (Portuguese) bank account to withdraw a maximum of 400 [[Euro]]s daily (holders of foreign accounts can withdraw more, depending on their bank). If the user fails to enter the correct [[Personal identification number|PIN]] after three attempts, the ATM will not return the card.{{cite web |url= http://www.sibs.pt/en/conteudo.php?id=148&type=0|title= ATM Network: Userful Information|accessdate= 2006-12-19|publisher = SIBS |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061003222427/http://www.sibs.pt/en/conteudo.php?id=148&type=0 |archivedate = 2006-10-03}} If the user fails to take the money out of the ATM after a certain period of time, the ATM takes back the cash to prevent theft.{{cite web |url= http://www.sibs.pt/en/conteudo.php?id=151&type=6#p3|title= ATM Network: FAQs|accessdate= 2006-12-19|publisher = SIBS |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061003222337/http://www.sibs.pt/en/conteudo.php?id=151&type=6#p3 |archivedate = 2006-10-03}} A recent security measure has been introduced under the form of a tinting mechanism that releases ink and stains the money in the event of forced opening of the ATM. When in possession of a tinted bill, one must report it to the police (for further investigation, as it is likely to be from a stolen ATM) and can later have it traded at a bank for a non-tinted one, without additional charges.{{cite web |url= http://www.clientebancario.com/2009/01/posse-de-notas-tintadas.html|title= Clientebancario.com - posse de notas tintadas}} ''(Portuguese)'' In addition to security cameras, many ATM terminals include a rear-view mirror above the interactive screen, and the money withdrawal slot is located at approximately waist-level, for quick and more secluded storage of the money. ==Other Multibanco Services== ===Pagamento Automático MB (Automatic Payment)=== The Multibanco Automatic Payment is an [[EFTPOS]] network which began operating in 1987. It allows electronic payments made at the point of sale, through the use of a system accepted card. Therefore, this service allows real time payments protected with security measures, with 266,000 such terminals on the network as of 2014. In 2014, 781 million payments were made using this system. ===MB PHONE=== MB PHONE{{cite web |url= http://www.sibs.pt/pt/mb/prodserv/mbphone/|title= SIBS: MB PHONE|accessdate= 2010-07-07|publisher = SIBS}} was launched as TeleMultibanco in 1996 and rebranded to the current designation in 2008.{{cite web |url= https://sic.sapo.pt/online/arquivo/2008/6/dinheiro/1/2008060+Renovacao+do+Multibanco.htm|title=SIC Online: Nova imagem e mais serviços|accessdate= 2010-07-07|publisher = SIC}} It allows its users to check their account balance and transactions, make transfers, service and shopping payments, and request [[cheque]] books through their mobile phones.{{cite web |url= http://www.sibs.pt/pt/mb/prodserv/mbphone/operacoes/|title= SIBS: Operações MB PHONE|accessdate= 2010-07-07|publisher = SIBS}} In 2009, around 3 million transactions were made by the 300,000 mobile phone clients using this system.{{cite web |url= http://www.sibs.pt/pt/mb/prodserv/mbphone/estatisticas/|title= SIBS: Estatísticas MB PHONE|accessdate= 2007-07-07|publisher = SIBS}} ===MB NET=== MB NET allows users to make payments through the [[Internet]] and it is set up for online shopping.{{cite web |url= http://www.sibs.pt/pt/mb/prodserv/mbnet/|title= SIBS: MB NET|accessdate= 2007-07-07|publisher = SIBS}} Over 1 million payments were made using MB NET in 2009.{{cite web |url= http://www.sibs.pt/pt/mb/prodserv/mbnet/estatisticas/|title= SIBS: Estatísticas MB NET|accessdate= 2007-07-07|publisher = SIBS}} MB NET allows the creation of virtual credit cards to be used online. Depending on the card system, one will get an [[American Express]], [[VISA]] or [[MasterCard]] virtual card. For example, if the card is a VISA or [[Visa Electron]] then the generated cards by MB NET are VISAs. This system is compatible with most payment systems, including PayPal and all places that accept credit cards as payment. To generate a virtual credit card one must login to the MB NET site and enter a limit. Then the site instantly gives the [[Payment card number|credit card number]] and security codes (CVC2 and CVV2) to pay for your online purchase. The number is also valid for offline purchases. The virtual cards allow for normal credit card interactions; either payment or crediting the holder's account. There are two types of virtual card—one for one-time use, and one meant for multiple uses. All cards are given a usable lifetime of between 1 and 12 months. More specifically, they are valid until the end of the month following the one when it is requested/issued. The great advantage of MB NET is that the customer's real payment details are never known to the vendor and the card's limit can be set according to the purchase's value. Even if a vendor or a hacker tries to extort a higher amount, the defined limit prevents it. Shopping online is hence made safer. Registration to use MB NET is required. To do so, one must go to a Multibanco ATM or one's [[home banking]] website (if the bank allows that operation on such a medium). The client sets a password but the username is given by the system. Registration links the MB NET service to a debit or credit card of one of the SIBS associated banking institutions that support it. ===Via Verde and Host to Host=== The automated toll payment service [[Via Verde]] is also operated by SIBS. Host to Host is the name given to the system that allows users to perform ATM transactions through their own bank site, enabling [[online banking]] which has been active since 2000.{{cite web |url= http://www.sibs.pt/en/conteudo.php?id=157&type=0|title= Multibanco: Others|accessdate= 2006-12-19|publisher = SIBS |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061003222245/http://www.sibs.pt/en/conteudo.php?id=157&type=0 |archivedate = 2006-10-03}} ==See also== *[[Euro Alliance of Payment Schemes]] ==Notes and references== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commonscat}} *[http://www.sibs.pt SIBS official site] {{Interbank networks}} [[Category:Financial services companies of Portugal]] [[Category:Interbank networks]]
